title: Reverted all guava list changes
NA
body: @wimjongman Wim, what can you do with this issue ?

title: NA
body: Do you think it will work with your new fix?

title: NA
body: Never mind., it is not related.

title: NA
body: @wimjongman do you know why Alexander decided to get rid of Guava ?

title: NA
body: @akurtakov can you elaborate?

title: NA
body:
Multiple reasons:
* Guava has CVEs quite often 
* Projects depend and thus contribute different versions of guava to simrel most often with very open version ranges leading to different installations on user machines based on what is installed first
* A lot of functionality provided by it is actually incorporated in newer Java versions

title: NA
body: I forgot to mention that I looked at that when I was the maintainer of Java EPP and tried to include WindowBuilder in it as CVEs and duplicated dependencies are a major concern for me. I stepped down as Java EPP maintainer and thus would not try to add WindowBuilder to it so no more interest from my side on the topic.

title: NA
body: Thank you @akurtakov for your answer, I close this bug

body:
I came across this annoying glitch or bug that makes the Windowbuilder basically unusable. So when adding in like composites, Eclipse starts to not respond and I have to restart, again I try and it does the same thing, so I restart again, then again, and again.

No crash logs or errors, eclipse just stops responding. Does anyone have any fix to this.

I am using Java 14 and using Eclipse 2020-09, as I believe, not at my computer right now to check, but I think that is it.

Any help is very appreciated.

title: Design Tab Has Blank Palette, Structure, and Design Area
body:
I've just started to try making applications using windowbuilder, but I have already met a serious problem that makes it impossible.
I have searched for hours online to no avail and tried common fixes for other similar issues - none of which have worked. When I follow the steps for making a new Swing or SWT application (both have this issue), the source code is correctly generated and runs but the design tab does not parse anything as I would expect.
**File structure of my project (ok to my knowledge):** 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70865538/116448677-62d13200-a827-11eb-9088-c6ca8088e2cb.png)
The parsing dialogue opens and closes instantly (reparsing does nothing either), and then I get this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70865538/116447522-13d6cd00-a826-11eb-9e3b-713945f0bc66.png)
I have tried a full clean reinstall of eclipse and windowbuilder which changed nothing.
- **Eclipse version:** 4.19
- **Windowbuilder version:** 1.9.6.pre (tried 1.9.5 too but it kept installing nightly along with it)
- **Other plugins:** none
- **Log file if useful (it goes over my head):** 
[.log](https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/files/6393732/default.log)
Any Help is much appreciated.

title: NA
body:
Hi

Thanks to the content of the log, I think that you're using JDK 16. We have an issue with a library used by WindowBuilder, and we're working on it (tough work).

Can you try to add the JVM parameter " --illegal-access=permit" in your Eclipse Configuration ?

Please keep us informed.

Laurent

title: NA
body:
Adding that parameter to the config file for Eclipse fixed the problem flawlessly!!
Excellent work, and good luck on fixing that library issue.
Your work is much appreciated!

title: NA
body: Thank you for your kind message and your support ;)

title: NA
body:
> Hi
> 
> Thanks to the content of the log, I think that you're using JDK 16. We have an issue with a library used by WindowBuilder, and we're working on it (tough work).
> 
> Can you try to add the JVM parameter " --illegal-access=permit" in your Eclipse Configuration ?
> 
> Please keep us informed.
> 
> Laurent

Hello, I am very very new to Eclipse IDE. Could you tell me pls how to do that?
"Can you try to add the JVM parameter " --illegal-access=permit" in your Eclipse Configuration ?"

title: NA
body:
Sure !

Go to your Eclipse directory and make a backup of your **eclipse.ini** file.

Open this **eclipse.ini** file, you'll find a parameter called "-vmargs" :
```
-vmargs
-Dosgi.requiredJavaVersion=11
-Dosgi.instance.area.default=@user.home/eclipse-workspace
-Dsun.java.command=Eclipse
-XX:+UseG1GC
...
```

Add the JVM parameter `--illegal-access=permit` at the end of the file.

Save and restart Eclipse.

Please keep us informed.

title: NA
body:
> Sure !

> Please keep us informed.

I don't know if I should start a new issue thread, but that doesn't seem to work. Should I start a new one to link my log File?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45139479/136701642-cf730554-a77a-4947-9abd-c84ef457bf7a.png)

But It doesn't help. My File structure of my project is just like from OP but with [jdk-17]. By running the GUI, the console states: "Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM warning: Ignoring option --illegal-access=permit; support was removed in 17.0"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45139479/136702176-f1997719-7503-41ad-8daf-839b7fcda25c.png)
I'm not new to Java itself, but new to Eclipse and all those setting of Java and Eclipse, which are really confusion. I dont't know what JDK or SE whatever I have to use etc. Any help would be appreciated.

title: NA
body:
Hi

Sorry I thought that you were using Java 16. For JDK17 you can have a look at issue #47 (https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/issues/47)

You have to add a new argument, but it seems that there is a problem with this JVM argument, so you have to create a bash file (or a bat file if you use Windows).

I hope this helps,

Laurent

title: NA
body: So just copy that script and save that as a bat file on Windows? Because I see the word Linux there in the script.

title: NA
body:
No, here is an example (we suppose that JDK 17 is installed in the directory `C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-17` and Eclipse in the directory `C;\Eclipse`)

Save these lines as a batch file :

```
"C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-17\bin\java" -jar c:\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.6.100.v20201223-0822.jar
-noverify
-Dosgi.requiredJavaVersion=11
-Dosgi.dataAreaRequiresExplicitInit=true
-Dorg.eclipse.swt.graphics.Resource.reportNonDisposed=true
-Xms256m
-Xmx2048m
--add-modules=ALL-SYSTEM
--add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED
-showsplash
```

title: NA
body:
And run that? Man I am way to lost to get this done. By running it nearly everytime it says couldn't be found or something or no access. And I found that in the error log:

"Designer [1.10.1.202106041225.202110102148]: Cannot invoke "org.eclipse.wb.core.model.ObjectInfo.getBroadcastObject()" because the return value of "org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.editor.DesignToolbarHelper.access$1(org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.editor.DesignToolbarHelper)" is null"

title: NA
body: Ok somehow on my Surface, the .bat can run and all. But there is still an empty Design Tab.

title: NA
body:
FYI, what worked for me is adding this to the end of the eclipse.ini
```
--add-opens=java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED
```
What does not work for me is adding this without the first `=`
```
--add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED
```
Nor this with two lines:
```
--add-opens
java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED
```
which I would have expected should work because all the documented examples I see are without an `=`.

title: NA
body:
None of this worked for my situation. I've got a Windows 10 machine with jdk-17 and eclipse Version: 2021-12 (4.22). I've added everything to the Eclipse.ini and created the bat file to load Eclipse as shown above and my swing designer palette is still empty with that pesky event loop exception still pooping up. Any ideas would be wonderful.

This seems relevant:
WARNING: A terminally deprecated method in java.lang.System has been called
WARNING: System::setSecurityManager has been called by org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.DesignerPlugin (file:/C:/Users/clegg/eclipse/jee-2021-12/eclipse/../../../.p2/pool/plugins/org.eclipse.wb.core_1.10.1.202106041225.jar)
WARNING: Please consider reporting this to the maintainers of org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.DesignerPlugin
WARNING: System::setSecurityManager will be removed in a future release

If you use JDK 17 adding parameters will be useless.

Laurent

body:

I receive an 'Unhandled event loop exception' exception (see attached) only when Eclipse runs JDK16.
When I use JDK16 for my workspace it works.

I use Eclipse 4.19 with JDK16 patches.

[stack2.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/files/6599755/stack2.txt)

https://github.com/projectlombok/lombok/pull/2811/commits/7069c7e90377952ae7c9a7dfd6786205dfe7ec5f

title: NA

title: NA
body: Bug fixed in WB 1.9.8

title: NA
body:
Laurent, if I understand correctly, this addition will allow cglib to keep running by calling the 'exportAllModulesToAllModules()' method? Is this done for the complete jvm?

https://www.burningwave.org/

title: NA
body: Yes wim, as far as I understand it is done for the complete JVM

title: NA
body:
> It works well when I use " --illegal-access=permit" (in eclipse.ini) as proposed by Laurent.

The argument --illegal-access=permit is no longer supported with Java 17.

title: NA
body: I don't think we need that anymore since we switched technologies. @lcaron can you confirm?

title: NA
body:
A while back, I added this to make it work with Java 17, but I don't know if that's still needed either:
```
--add-opens=java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED
```

title: NA
body:
> I don't think we need that anymore since we switched technologies. @lcaron can you confirm?

Yes, in recent versions [`--illegal-access=permit` is not used/required anymore](https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/commit/052cf368a80bdd0659cf98679f9ee8c709d4c8cd#diff-8cee4dfac1ee9c8899db3061a385ebe28cdbea2ebb509e46e1126036101656a0).

See also https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/pull/280 (not yet released)

title: NA
body:
The trick with `--illegal-access=permit` was necessary with Java 16, but it is no longer supported in Java 17.

Anyway the latest release of WB runs without additionnal VM parameter on Java 16+

title: NA
body:
Hi Alex,

To help us, can you please try to run Eclipse with another JDK ? I want to know if the issue is due to the latest release of Eclipse or due to JDK 17.

title: NA
body:
Hi Laurent,

Yes, I am almost sure it is due to the JDK17 (JEP 403: Strongly Encapsulate JDK Internals)
It seems **--illegal-access=permit** does not work anymore ...
I tried to add **--add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED** to eclipse.ini but without success Eclipse does not start with this JVM argument.

So I created my own script to start Eclipse with **--add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED**

> #!/bin/bash
> /jvm/openjdk/jdk-17/bin/java -jar \
> -noverify \
> -Dosgi.requiredJavaVersion=11 \
> -Dosgi.dataAreaRequiresExplicitInit=true \
> -Dorg.eclipse.swt.graphics.Resource.reportNonDisposed=true \
> -Xms256m \
> -Xmx2048m \
> -Djava.library.path=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/jni \
> --add-modules=ALL-SYSTEM \
> --add-opens java.base/java.lang=ALL-UNNAMED \
> /home/didiot/0_eclipse_4.21/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.6.300.v20210813-1054.jar \
> -showsplash
> 

With this start script : WB works correctly.

Best Regards,
Alex

Holy thank you. It does work. Now I have several questions I hope you could answer.

1. Should this type of problem be normal?
2. Is there an easy way to get this going on my PC too, or do you have to create a custom environment made by you too?
3. Shouldn't be launching and using an add-on in Eclipse (or generally in any software) be easy in simple?
4. Will there be an update where WindowBuilder shouldn't be that difficult to use? (except if I have done something wrong on BOTH my PC and Surface)
5. What JRE (or SE or JDK whatever I don't understand the term) am I using with that now? Is it using JDK 17, because that is what I would like to use.
6. (If this is my fault on both devices) What the hell made all of this so difficult?

title: NA
body:
Hi Tim

I'll try to explain the best I can with my bad English. 

WindowBuilder is using a very old library to manipulate bytecode (cglib, not maintained anymore). Since JDK 9, this library generates a lot of warning, but it works. Since JDK 16 it breaks WindowBuilder, except if you add the VM parameter `--illegal-access=permit.`
Since Java 17 this parameter is no longer supported, so **WB is not working anymore**.

We are trying to replace cglib by bytebuddy but it's a tricky and long work.

**a) Should this type of problem be normal?**
Normal, no. Logical yes.

**2) Is there an easy way to get this going on my PC too, or do you have to create a custom environment made by you too?**
There is a solution: you can download Eclipse IDE with an embedded JRE (https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/). Eclipse will run with this JRE instead of 
your own JDK. Because this JRE is OpenJDK 16, once you have added the parameter --illegal-access=permit it will work flawlessly.
(the installation I proposed to you contains Eclipse IDE For Java, Windowbuilder and OpenJDK 16 embedded. The VM parameter has been added to the eclipse.ini file)

**3) Shouldn't be launching and using an add-on in Eclipse (or generally in any software) be easy in simple?**
See answer 2 (download Eclipse with embedded JRE)

**4) Will there be an update where WindowBuilder shouldn't be that difficult to use? (except if I have done something wrong on BOTH my PC and Surface)**
Yes I am working on this topic, and I hope that I'll finish it in the next few weeks.

**5) What JRE (or SE or JDK whatever I don't understand the term) am I using with that now? Is it using JDK 17, because that is what I would like to use.
(If this is my fault on both devices) What the hell made all of this so difficult?**

For the moment, the only solution is to run Eclipse with JDK 16 or lower. You can use JDK 17 in your projects if you declare this JRE (Window > Preferences > Installed JREs), but not for running the IDE.


I hope I answered your questions.

title: Clarification on WindowBuilder and Apple Silicon M1 machines
body:
I currently use a intel mac and would like to move to a Apple Silicon Mac but I'm not clear about what will and won't work. First of all I'm unclear as to the status of an arm version of Eclipse, I would prefer to stay with the Intel version if it's not production ready. The main question would be the status of plugins for eclipse. I assume plain java only plugins will be ok but I was not sure about SWT. I don't use SWT in my Java applications but if WindowBuilder requires it and there isn't an arm version of SWT / Windobuilder then obviously that would mean sticking with intel code for now. 

If rosetta2 allows me to run all my current dev tools that will be fine, it's just a little fuzzy about how rosetta2 works. I understand that is converts apps when they are installed into Apple Silicon arm code. So for example if I unzip a copy of ANT into folder will that count as installing. I did read an article about opening a terminal in intel compatibility mode.

At the moment there are so many variables and information overload I simply don't know which path to follow. All ARM or all Intel.

If anyone has arm Eclipse with WindowBuilder running or has any experiences which would help my decision making that would be perfect.

Can you mix and match - install arm version of Java JDK and Intel version of Eclipse for example ?

Using Zulu Java 11 LTS and Eclipse EE 2021.9 with WindowBuilder and JasperStudio plugins.

Dave

title: NA
body:
There are aarch64 versions of  SWT, the Eclipse SDK since the current release,   the Eclipse Installer for the upcoming release, for the EPP package for 2021-12 M12 (for the upcoming release), for JustJ's JREs for Java 17.  E.g., https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/release/2021-12/m2

So you should expect that mostly the ARM version of Eclipse will work well.   As far as I understand it you can use/run either Intel or ARM on an M1 just fine.  I also understand it that your JDK and your Eclipse must both be Intel or both be ARM versions, i.e., they must match.

Perhaps you could test the ARM-based installer:

https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/oomph/epp/2021-12/M2/eclipse-inst-jre-mac-aarch64.dmg

I.e., use it set up a BIRT development environment:

https://www.eclipse.org/setups/installer/?url=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/master/setups/WindowBuilderConfiguration.setup&show=true

title: NA
body:
I will certainly try. It’s about 3 weeks before my machine arrives so I’m trying to research as much as I can in advance.

Question - what does the M2 in the eclipse link signify ?

My shopping list (setup on new Mac) will be

Java 8 JDK
Java 11 JDK
Apache Tomcat 9 & 10
Eclipse IDE Enterprise Edition 2021-?? latest
WindowBuilder Pro Plugin
JasperReports Studio Plugin
MySQL Database
ANT Command Line Build Tool
MAVEN Command Line Build Tool

The latter 2 items are a bit of a question mark. If I unzip the intel binary into a non Applications folder will rosetta2 convert them to Apple Silicon format.

The more I think about it the more I think of questions. You say that Eclipse and JDK should both be either Intel or ARM - however lets say I need Java 11 arm for Eclipse for Java 11 x86 for ANT - how on earth do you install both and if you do how do you distinguish between them. Sounds like a recipe for disaster if you get mixed up.

Thanks for you reply.

Dave

I'm sure someone will need to investigate how to update these things to produce Aarch64 versions for Mac (and Linux).

The stuff at https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/tree/master/org.eclipse.wb.os.macosx/native/mac

title: "Restore default value" on Layout property causes the Layout property to disappear
body:
The "Restore default value" feature on the Layout property causes the Layout property to disappear. 

Steps to replicate:
1. Select any other layout other than BorderLayout (as BorderLayout is the default).
2. Right click on the layout property and from the context menu select "Restore default value"

The property can be restored by using the Undo option or the by closing the editor and re-opening the editor.

I'm currently trying to fix this issue, but I would like to know if anyone has some more insight as to what might be causing the issue?

title: NA
body: The setValue method in the LayoutInfo class just ran a "delete" method. I have removed the "delete" method and altered the setValue method to set a default layout (i.e. BorderLayout). The delete method is still called on the older layout within the "setLayout" method of the parent container.

title: NA
body: Marcel, I think that the default layout is an absolute layout (no layout). Is there not a preference value that declares the default layout? If we pick a hardcoded default I suggest to use filllayout or gridlayout.

title: NA
body:
@wimjongman I have not seen a default value yet but I could be wrong. I can set it to the use the flowLayout or gridlayout no problem. I just used what was the default layout set when creating a new screen. 

UPDATE: I have found the preferences for this option and I am adjusting the code to take the value set in the preferences. However, the preference could be set to "Implicit (default) layout" in this case the preferences return a null and in this case I'll set it to flowLayout

title: NA
body: @wimjongman Did you mean flowLayout or gridLayout? I do not see a fillLayout? For the time being I'll use gridlayout

title: NA
body: Maybe FillLayout is not a layout in swing? I don't know what the goto layout is in Swing.

title: NA
body: Yes it seems to be an SWT layout. I have used the default GridLayout. For the case when no specific default is set in the preferences

title: Creating Color Picker Preferences
body:
We require the ability to select which color pickers are available when selecting the foreground/background of a widget. 

Previously all the color pickers were available at all times and there was no easy way to hide them, other than removing them from the WindowBuilder. 
Previously the color chooser (for swing widgets) would display the following Color chooser dialog:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/142982050-89ce1ea7-4a00-4ee2-88f8-47683c6d6feb.png)

I have therefore created a preference page in the WindowBuilder category called "Color Chooser". On this preference page it is now able to select which of the color pickers to include in this dialog.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/142982224-24e3a93e-0155-4867-a3c3-c85d534f3bb1.png)

Along with this I have also added a "Custom Colors" color picker that allows the user to specify any color that may or may not appear on any of the other color pickers. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/142982420-765fed69-5a1e-4c9c-a546-fb1082f88f52.png)

Another small addition to this Color Chooser dialog is that of the warning on the "System colors" tab. This warning has been added to warn the user of the change that may occur in the selected colors depending current system.
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/142982645-4d042341-ee17-4337-a845-b710161ab814.png)

Linked to PR #91

title: NA
body: Very nice, brother. Thanks!

title: Obtaining the GraphicalViewer object form DesignComposite
body:
We need the ability to obtain the GraphicalViewer object from the DesignComposite. This is so that we can use it in our application specific drag and drop feature.

I have added a public getter method to the DesignComposite class

see PR #106

title: Hiding/Showing Windowbuilder toolbars
body:
We needed the capability to hide the Windowbuilder toolbar as our application has its own toolbar that have similar functionality but not the same. Therefore to have both toolbars visible would cause confusion and interference. 

The problem was that there was no way to hide this toolbar from our application without altering the Windowbuilder itself. 

To solve this issue I have added a class called DesignCompositeManager that is used within Windowbuilder to determine whether to hide or show the WB toolbar. 

This is done by creating the DesignCompositeManager object and passing it into the constructor of the DesignerEditor in our application. 

The default for Windowbuilder looks as follows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/143411663-d7c25a4f-d6d7-490a-9d40-49a78876750b.png)

After setting the toolbar to be hidden it looks as follows:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/143412061-76c4011d-bb0c-4620-bf42-8c475f3288c0.png)

body:
> Why did you delete .eclipse and .p2 directories?
> 
> Can you describe the whole run? First, you installed Eclipse and then installed WB into it?

I was just honestly guessing what to do. Some guides online that I followed for previous problems when I wanted to 'completely delete Eclipse' was to delete those two directories along with the Eclipse installation. It helped me with past problems, so I thought of doing it with this one. 

> Mmmh weird, this problem occured with previous versions of WB. Did you try with the latest snapshot ?

If by latest snapshot you mean the latest WindowBuilder, I tried the 'Current' version available according to [this link](https://www.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/download.php). I will try the 'Upcoming' version later and report what happens on that.

If you mean the latest Eclipse version, I am running the latest version available on Manjaro, with Eclipse's 'Check for updates' function yielding 'No updates found'.

title: Limited options for Design Context Menu
body:
We need the ability to hide the options from the context menu that are not used and could cause problems with our existing implementations. I.e. we need to be able to only show the basic actions in the context menu such as the Cut, Copy, Paste and Delete actions. 

Solution description: I have added preferences to the DesignContextMenuProvider class in the buildContextMenu method. These preferences are not available to the user but can be set by using the InstanceScope. The default for these preferences are set to true and therefore will always show all the actions as previously defined unless the developer incorporating windowbuilder into their product sets the preferences to false.

The two preferences are:
1. To hide the same actions as are found on the Windowbuilder toolbar, i.e. the Test and Refresh actions
2. To hide object specific actions that vary depending on which object the context menu is invoked

Following are screenshots of the context menu:
When preferences are set to true
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/145164346-04a623ee-f601-4cde-9bb1-93f0d8128c91.png)

When the toolbar preference is set to false
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/145164905-ee0040e4-56ea-41ca-b665-4bd5f3c17698.png)

When the object specific preference is set to false
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/145165005-ce20e17f-0d8e-40f3-8383-11a55a8c02ae.png)

When both are set to false and only the basic actions remain
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/145165099-ea7020d5-77aa-4517-a711-4b27917ea87c.png)

title: NA
body:
cglib is a code generation library WB uses. WB ships it under org.eclipse.wb.runtime.lib. You either dont have this bundle or it doesnt get loaded. You can start by checking if it exists at all. It should be in your plugins' folder (Keep in mind that Eclipse installer keeps the p2 pool somewhere in user.home by default so the real deal should be there and not in eclipse's installation path)
(and btw change the title it has nothing to do with Java 17 or Eclipse 2021-12)

The argument --illegal-access=permit is no longer supported with Java 17.

The current snapshot release (https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/lastgoodbuild/) should solve this problem. Did you try with this version ?

title: Document the release process of WB
body:
AFAIR @wimjongman handled in the past years the release of WB. We should document the process in the source code, so that we can look it up.

IIRC we following is necessary:

1.) a release record: https://projects.eclipse.org/projects/tools.windowbuilder/releases/
2.) Run the release job on Jenkins
3.) Update the Simrel record
4.) Maybe need a release review from the foundation

(wim)
The following is also required after release
* Update marketplace versions
* Increment feature versions
* Update the website https://www.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/download.php

@wimjongman is that sufficient for the release?

title: NA
body: Started a wiki here: https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/wiki/Release-Checklist

body:
Hi @vogella 

Can you give more information ?

I was able to "play" with WB with Java 17. Here is what I did with Fedora release 29 + GTK 3.14
1) Install Java 17 (Oracle) 
2) Install Eclipse 2021-12 for Commiters. Eclipse runs with the JDK 17 I've installed before
3) Install WB latest good build (drag n'drop from https://www.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/download.php)
4) Create a new SWT project

Do you want me to try with Open JDK 17 ?

title: WindowBuilder empty palette Java 17 installed in RCP
body:
I still get an empty palette with Java 17 when I install the latest WindowBuilder plugin in my RCP application with the p2 Update Manager. In Eclipse however it seems to work. The following error is thrown when I open and click on the design tab:

```
java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "org.eclipse.wb.core.model.ObjectInfo.getBroadcastObject()" because "this.this$0.m_rootObject" is null
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.editor.structure.components.ComponentsTreePage$5.run(ComponentsTreePage.java:157)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.utils.execution.ExecutionUtils.runLog(ExecutionUtils.java:106)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.editor.structure.components.ComponentsTreePage.selectGraphicalViewer(ComponentsTreePage.java:148)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.editor.structure.components.ComponentsTreePage$1.selectionChanged(ComponentsTreePage.java:119)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.gef.core.AbstractEditPartViewer.fireSelectionChanged(AbstractEditPartViewer.java:202)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.gef.core.AbstractEditPartViewer.deselectAll(AbstractEditPartViewer.java:325)
	at org.eclipse.wb.gef.graphical.tools.SelectionTool.handleButtonDown(SelectionTool.java:139)
	at org.eclipse.wb.gef.core.tools.Tool.mouseDown(Tool.java:385)
	at org.eclipse.wb.gef.graphical.tools.SelectionTool.mouseDown(SelectionTool.java:238)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.gef.core.EditDomain.mouseDown(EditDomain.java:244)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.gef.tree.TreeEventManager.mouseDown(TreeEventManager.java:114)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:78)
	at java.base/jdk.internal.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
	at java.base/java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:567)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.draw2d.EventManager$1.invoke(EventManager.java:317)
	at jdk.proxy9/jdk.proxy9.$Proxy23.mouseDown(Unknown Source)
```

With Java <16 there was no problem. I also tried a fresh installation with the latest built to no avail.

I can reproduce this error on MacOSX and Windows using
Eclipse Adoptium, java.version: 17.0.1
WindowBuilder version: 1.9.7.202112211354

title: Scaling issue in WindowBuilder when Windows Scaling is not at 100%
body:
If Windows scaling for text, applications and elements is NOT set to 100% WindowBuilder will not show the right scaling for the components. The frame icon has double of is's normal size and close, minimize and maximize button wont show up.

I'm using all latest versions that are available and also did a completly reinstall Eclipse, WindowBuilder als well as JDK 17
Steps to reproduce

1. Go to your Windows settings.
2. Go to "System".
3. If not already open, klick on "Display"
4. Set "Scaling and arrangement" to something other than 100%
5. In my case I got an 13.5", 3000 x 2000 Display where it's 200% scaling factor is necessary.
6. Start Eclipse, open a project, open the file with WindwoBuilder, create what ever frame you want and go to the "Desing" page.
7. What is the current bug behavior?

I'm not 100% sure but I thing that even while Eclipse seems to understand that Windows scaling is active, this information is somehow not providet to WindowBuilder. Even when setting auto scaling to 100% at the eclipse.ini file only fontsize and icon size that are part of the Eclipse UI change but NOT those from WindowBuilder.

I also tried to change the properties of Eclipse.exe file with my default Windows Scaliung at 200% and nothing addet to the .ini file. Therefor I searched that file, right klicked on it, went down to properties, then to compatibility and ther on "change high-DPI settings. There I enabled the overwriting of high-DPI scaling and change it to System (Extended).

Confirm both Windows and (re)start eclipse. Now WindowBuilder shows the right scaling but if you hover your mouse over the "Source" and "Desing" fields at the bottom left they disappear but you can still klick them. If you press ssome random button or field or just switch to an other application the show back up.
What is the expected correct behavior?

The same as when scaling is at 100%.

Scaling at 1
![Eclipse](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/89223042/148819177-80a3f1db-aae3-4cd9-aed6-3b483e704c42.jpg)

Scaling at 200% Eclipse2
![Eclipse2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/89223042/148819189-4cba85b6-d709-45d2-a7c0-352af1a5ae2e.jpg)

title: NA
body:
Hi

First of all I would like to thank you for this very clear and precise description.

The original code of WB was designed when scaling was not possible, so this behaviour is not a surprise. It needs to be investigated.

title: NA
body:
> Hi
> 
> First of all I would like to thank you for this very clear and precise description.
> 
> The original code of WB was designed when scaling was not possible, so this behaviour is not a surprise. It needs to be investigated.

I would like to add, that if you use WB with that first **work around** you may get into trouble when running your code. In my case I wondert why my window was not abel to display everyting in it's setted size. I recognized, that if you use Window Builder with a different scaling than 100% Windows also scales up or down the size of elements and text in your frame by the factor you choose in the Windows settings. Windows scaling does **NOT** affect the minimum size yout set for your window. But I'm not sure if it is the same for the prefered size because if you run the code, the frame shows up as it should. Only if you start to downsize it you will notice that its behavior is different than on 100% scaling.

title: NA
body:
### **NEW Workaround for HDPI-Displays:** 

Set your Windows scaling to 100% and lower your resolution to a scaling where it's easy to read the displyed text and icons. 
I know it might be a bit annoying but with this you can solve both issues at once.

title: Update plugin version number
body: Plugins version numbers are not consistent with the major version number.

title: NA
body:
They don't need to be.  However, 

* for every non-breaking change the maintenance segment should be incremented (e.g. with 20)
* for every new non-breaking feature, the minor segment should be upgraded

Closing.

title: Hiding of Advanced Properties and Events Actions
body:
We require the ability to hide the advanced properties and events actions on the Components Properties view toolbar. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/150114781-2779e009-73b8-4640-aa1e-74ac32650a92.png)

title: Hiding of buttons on Exception and Warning dialogs
body:
We require the ability to hide the following buttons:

Exception dialog:
- Contact support
- Refresh
- Switch to Code

Warning dialog:
- Refresh 
- Switch to code

title: Renaming the root object in the Tree view
body:
We require the ability to set the root object name in the tree view, instead of using the fully qualified name.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92920738/150292198-cf8d348d-7a60-444c-910a-8ccd4e1277a7.png)

title: NA
body:
![eclipse change element name](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/89223042/150312811-8dcbf42d-2a1e-412c-b1ac-bfec5a89c5a2.jpg)

1. Choose the element you want to rename.

The "Properties" window/panel should now show up all variables that you can change. 

2. Click into the field next to "Variable" this should be the first row. 

You could also change the name of elements in your source code but it's much more worke and could also bringup new issues.

title: Windowbuilder Basic UI Layouts
body:
We require that certain layouts be hidden within the Windowbuilder Basic UI. The only layouts that should be available for the user to use in the WB Basic UI are: Absolute Layout, Box Layout, Grid Layout and GridBag Layout.

This should be reflected in the Layouts dropdown option of the properties view.

title: NA
body: Closed with https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/pull/182

title: Palette Layout preferences required
body:
We require the ability to adjust the layout of the editor palette. This should be done with a context menu instead of requiring the user to go to the preferences and adjust settings. The layout should be able to be set as a List, Columns, Icons with description or Icons only.

A settings dialog should also be accessible allowing the user to set the Font style and size of the description text and the category heading respectively.

title: Lambda Support
body:
WindowBuilder does not recognize lambda expressions, for example:
    addHelpListener(e -> System.out.println("Help!"));

Support for lambda expressions should be added to enable transition to new coding style where a lot of code is written in lambdas.

WindowBuilder Version: 1.9.7.202112020939

title: NA
body:
The problem is located in line 105.

https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/blob/2581b56875d2f99498ef224a0eb59212694754f2/org.eclipse.wb.core.java/src/org/eclipse/wb/internal/core/utils/jdt/core/CodeUtils.java#L101-L112

From the JavaDoc:

> JLS3 is a superset of all earlier versions of the
> Java language, and the JLS3 API can be used to manipulate
> programs written in all versions of the Java language
> up to and including J2SE 5 (aka JDK 1.5).

I.e. the parser ignores all language features past Java 5. That should be easy to fix once the master is stable again.

title: Set availability of certain Layouts
body:
We need the ability to hide/show certain layouts. This should affect the layouts displayed in the context menu, designer palette and the dropdown list. 

For example a user should be able to specify what layouts should be available in a preference page, this should include layouts of Swing and SWT. If a user selects, say Border Layout and BoxLayout from the Swing layouts preference page and FillLayout and Form Layout from the SWT layouts page. Only these layouts should be available to use by the user.

### To Reproduce
A bit difficult. It needs a 3-Project-Setup and does only occur when using Maven™:
Project 1 (LibProject) is a Standard-Maven-Project. It defines a class `de.custom.CustomFrame` like this:
```java
package de.custom;

import java.awt.Cursor;
import javax.swing.JFrame;

public class CustomFrame extends JFrame{
	public CustomFrame() {
		this.setCursor(Cursor.getPredefinedCursor(Cursor.CROSSHAIR_CURSOR));
	}
}
```
With this, you do a `mvn install` and **delete the project from the workspace**.

Project 2 (ParentProject) is a Standard-Maven-Project. It defines _nothing_, but exports its entries in the project-properties via Java Build Path → Order and Export → Check 'Maven Dependencies'.

Project 3 (ChildProject) is _not_ a Maven-Project, but a standard Java-Project. It defines Project 2 (ParentProject) as a Project dependency via Java Build Path → Projects → Add → Parent Project. It has a class `my.custom.frame.MyFrame` like this:
```java
package my.custom.frame;

import java.awt.BorderLayout;
import de.custom.CustomFrame;

public class MyFrame extends CustomFrame {
	public MyFrame() {
		buildFrame();
	}

	private void buildFrame() {
		setLayout(new BorderLayout());
		pack();
		setLocationRelativeTo(null);
		setVisible(true);
	}
}
```
When trying to open above class in the WindowBuilder design tab, the error occurs.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45291670/162917136-c0973be9-c74b-4f2d-8a70-9ba3fdb3a436.png)

I have also exported the projects to a zip, but GitHub won't let me upload it 😢. If you need it, I can try it again later...

### Expected Behaviour
WindowBuilder does not fail and opens the UI. 😃 

### Environment
Operating System: Windows 10 Enterprise 20H2
Eclipse: Version: 2021-12 (4.22.0) (20211202-1639) (I can also recreate the error in 4.20.0.20210612-1200 with WindowBuilder 1.9.7.202202142029)
WindowBuilder: 1.10.0.202203191024
All Projects with Java 8

body: Please note that GEF classes in WB were not the same as Eclipse GEF at that time. I don't remember the details now, but we replaced standard GEF with our own implementation due to lack of some functionality in the standard GEF. So replacing it with modern Eclipse GEF won't be easy at all. And I actually think that it's not so worth.

title: NA
body:
As @amitin mentioned, one of the big challenges is going to be the separation of the WB extensions from the original GEF code.

Given the scope of this task, I think it makes sense to split this migration into two parts: Draw2D and GEF.

I've started looking at the Draw2D classes and while it's going to be a lot of work, I think it's definitely possible to get the changes here reintegrated into GEF.

Luckily, there are quite a lot of JUnit tests for both Draw2D and GEF. So if all of them remain green, I think there's a good chance that the functionality of WB remains unaffected.

title: NA
body:
CGLib hasn't been updated in 4 years and according to their GitHub [repository](https://github.com/cglib/cglib), it is no longer being actively maintained.

> IMPORTANT NOTE: cglib is unmaintained and does not work well (or possibly at all?) in newer JDKs, particularly JDK17+. If you need to support newer JDKs, we will accept well-tested well-thought-out patches... but you'll probably have better luck migrating to something like [ByteBuddy](https://bytebuddy.net/).

It seems like other major projects (Spring/JUnit/Eclipse) have moved to ByteBuddy instead. We should probably try to get rid of this dependency, instead of just swapping it out with the latest Maven artifact.

title: NA
body:
The embedded CGLib jars have been removed with 6eb69f05bed774bc4f7d6f21b7176289ea7c8fb0.

CGLib is no longer maintained, so over the course of several commits, we have slowly migrated WB to ByteBuddy. This dependency is now contributed via the SimRel update site.

title: Fix deprecated use of new Integer/Double etc in Code Generation
body:
If I set a JSpinner to an Integer model, the code generated looks like: 
`this.spinner.setModel(new SpinnerNumberModel(new Integer(0), new Integer(0), null, new Integer(1)));`
which provides warnings with JDKs > 9, as the constructor Integer(int) is deprecated since version 9. 

The code should look like this: 
`this.spinner.setModel(new SpinnerNumberModel(Integer.valueOf(0), Integer.valueOf(0), null, Integer.valueOf(1)));`

It's probably the same with the other NumberModels too, e.g. Double, Float, ...

title: NA
body:
This should hopefully be fixed with #552.
In short, I have adapted a large part of the code base to use ImageDescriptors whenever possible and only create Images when needed. The class who is creating the image is then also responsible for disposing it, once no longer needed.
This shift of responsiblity should make it much less likely for errors like this to show up and also make it much easier to resolve.
There are still some sections where we still use images, but as far as I can tell, they are disposed properly. So it's not an immediate issue to change those parts as well.

title: Replace Guava Lists.newArrayList(); with new ArrayList<>();
body: AFAICS Guava Lists.newArrayList(); simply delegates to new ArrayList<>(); in WB therefore we can use this standard Java construct.

title: NA
body: With #663, the last remaining dependency to Guava has been removed. We now either use the corresponding Java methods directly or Commons Collections (for e.g. BidiMaps).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70652978/227604652-e24163ab-e64a-4d15-b483-da739b71011e.png)

A search led me to [Bug 570994](https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=570994), which seems to describe exactly the same behavior. And from what I understand, this is not an Eclipse issue, but rather some weird configuration on my system that's causing those artifacts.

Do we have any GTK experts who might have an idea what's going on here?

title: New Error The project cannot be built until its prerequisite org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment is built.
body:
In the latest WindowBuilder master I get the following error message:

 Description	Resource	Path	Location	Type
The project cannot be built until its prerequisite org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment is built. Cleaning and building all projects is recommended	org.eclipse.wb.dev		Unknown	Java Problem

The only changes in master from last week (there I did not see this error), were the commits from @howlger 

423160263a3b1ba75773282ed8da6859375e6843
82954c4de6009cd4c78b1bf0785db78a0f16f023

Both seemed unrelated. If I do clean project sufficiently (2-3 times) the error goes away but reappears.

@HannesWell are you aware of any changes in PDE? org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment is a fragment so I do not see why org.eclipse.wb.dev should depend on it.

title: NA
body:
> @HannesWell are you aware of any changes in PDE? org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment is a fragment so I do not see why org.eclipse.wb.dev should depend on it.

Sorry, unfortunately no immediate idea why this happens from my side.

title: NA
body:
> org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment is a fragment so I do not see why org.eclipse.wb.dev should depend on it.

The fragment host of `org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment` is `org.eclipse.jdt.core` on which `org.eclipse.wb.dev` depends. So in order to build `org.eclipse.wb.dev`, `org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment` has to build first.

I don't see project build cycles, but many projects with a nested _requires-to-build-first_ structure, e.g.
* org.eclipse.wb.tests
  * org.eclipse.wb.rcp.databinding.xwt
    * org.eclipse.wb.rcp.databinding
      * org.eclipse.wb.rcp
        * org.eclipse.wb.core.java
          * (via org.eclipse.jdt.core) org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment 

or
* org.eclipse.wb.tests
  * org.eclipse.wb.rcp.databinding.xwt
    * org.eclipse.wb.xwt
      * org.eclipse.wb.rcp
        * org.eclipse.wb.swt
          * (via org.eclipse.jdt.core) org.eclipse.wb.jdt.fragment

Does in the preferences _General > Workspace > Build_ increasing _Max iterations when building with cycles_ help?

I bet @mickaelistria could tell us how to trace the iterations of the project builders.

title: NA
body:
> I bet @mickaelistria could tell us how to trace the iterations of the project builders.

In Launch Configuration dialog > Trace > Enable Tracing > org.eclipse.core.resources; check what seems interesting. See also https://github.com/mickaelistria/eclipse-ide-parallel-builds-demo I used to generate some Gantt charts a while ago, but it's not just plug'n'play IIRC you need to modify some code to get everything working.

title: NA
body: Is this problem still relevant? I've never seen an error like this show up in the workspace. So I assume whatever caused this has long been fixed.

title: NA
body: The fragment was never included in any release and has been removed by #734. Whatever caused this issue should've become obsolete, now that it is gone.

> thanks for the info i tryed the nightly build it did no good would not install here are some screen shots showing the issues have never been able to install any nightly builds FYI i am runnung ubuntu 22.04

It seems like that due to very strict lower bound of ASM, WindowBuilder requires a higher version than what is provided by the Eclipse 4.27 (or older).

The issue is resolved now and the matching nightly build should be available soon. My apologies for the inconvenience.

title: Databinding binds to deprecated classes
body:
The databinding process binds to deprecated classes. It is, for example, the default to import
`import org.eclipse.jface.databinding.swt.WidgetProperties;` which is directly marked deprecated
and requests change to `import org.eclipse.jface.databinding.swt.typed.WidgetProperties;`

Additionally, if one manualy changes to the non-deprecated classes, they are not marked as bound anymore.

body: Thanks for reporting, Marco. Can you make a patch?

![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7570617/196231216-d2b1be41-3815-4728-8b81-487dab90b49b.PNG)
![Capture2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7570617/196231324-011bcfb8-3b0b-460f-a57d-f2880e16eea9.PNG)


Unknown GUI toolkit

The parser parsed the compilation unit, but can't identifyany GUI toolkit, so WindowBuilder can't display any GUI to edit. This can be caused by one of thefollowing reasons: 
•This class is not an editable UI class and contains no UI components.
•WindowBuilder does not recognize the GUI toolkit or library used in this class.
•WindowBuilder does not understand this GUI type/pattern in a supported GUI toolkit.
•Problems exist with the classpath. For example, the compilation unit uses SWT classes, but theSWT/JFace libraries are not included into the classpath.

title: WindowBuilder not showing in Eclipse after downloading
body: So Ive been trying to download WindowBuilder for Eclipse but it won't work. I have tried downloading straight from the marketplace and from Eclipse.org but nothing works. When it installs and restarts, I am unable to open or create a file with WindowBuilder. I have deleted and reinstalled WindowBuilder several times. I have tried different versions, but nothing works. I have deleted my meta data folder but that didn't work either. In Eclipse-workspace > .metadata >.plugins there are no WindowBuilder files but it says it is installed when I check my marketplace. I am on the latest version of Eclipse. Everything is up to date (in the marketplace picture it says update after I delete it and reinstall it. I have already updated it and still nothing worked). 48-2a86-4025-aca9-05a0e1a0068a.png">

title: Empty Design tab on Mac M1 Pro
body: Hello, I'm trying to use Eclipse and Window Builder to make an SWT project, but and have the following issue. The file compiles and executes well: I have tried lots of different versions of JDK, Eclipse and WB. Currently, I have the following versions. **Window Builder** **Eclipse version:** Version: 2022-12 M1 (4.26.0 M1) **Java:** JDK 18 There aren't errors or warnings, only the issue explained above. Could you help me?

title: NA
body: I have uninstalled the Eclipse and Dark Theme. Nothing changed. In order to give more information, when I create a **Swing -->Application Window** , the Design tab works fine but after Run As --> Java application It doesn't run. **Design tab on Swing Application Window** **Design tab on SWT Application Window** So, I suspect that the problem could be on referenced Libraries which use SWT. Information details of WindowBuilder **installed**

title: NA
body:
This does not look like a bug of WindowBuilder, but a misconfiguration of the _Java Build Path_ of your project for SWT.

Follow the [SWT documentation](https://www.eclipse.org/swt/eclipse.php) (in your case, for macOS on Apple silicon (M1), download and use [`swt-4.25-cocoa-macosx-aarch64.zip`](https://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/eclipse/downloads/drops4/R-4.25-202208311800/swt-4.25-cocoa-macosx-aarch64.zip)).

title: Update version number to 1.12.0
body: Bump the version numbers to the new release.

title: NA
body: Fixed

title: [SWT] Empty Design tab on Mac M1 Pro
body: ### Discussed in https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/discussions/340 **Problem**: The Design Tab is empty and It doesn't allow it to work. **Architecture**: Apple Silicon (aarch64) **Screenshot of the issue** **Eclipse version:** 2022-09 (4.25.0) **Build id:** 20220908-1902 **WindowBuilder version** There are no error messages. The same tests on Eclipse x86_64 emulated by Rosseta2 work. Details of the Eclipse x86_64 version: 2022-09 (4.25.0) Build id: 20220908-1902 Screenshot: The file which I tested is the following: [hi.txt](https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/files/9851684/hi.txt)

title: NA
body: I can't see that the native parts responsible for visual design pane representation are built for aarch64. So in order to get it working natively for aarch64 the code at https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/tree/master/org.eclipse.wb.os.macosx/native/mac must be built for aarch64 and the result binaries should reside at https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/tree/master/org.eclipse.wb.os.macosx/os/macosx/aarch64 directory

title: NA
body:
<strike>We don't check-in binaries.</strike>

Strike that, we do deliver those binaries. @amitin are you able to build those?

title: NA
body: Yes. I see that we do not build for aarch64. Thanks for finding that.

title: NA
body:
@wimjongman, I built it but I can't test it. I put the binary here https://github.com/amitin/windowbuilder
Please merge, test it and update your pull request if it works.

title: NA
body: Alexander, thanks! I cannot create the pull request for you. You have to do it for Eclipse legal reasons.

title: NA
body: Alexander, just create a PR from your repo with the added binaries.

title: NA
body:
> Alexander, thanks! I cannot create the pull request for you. You have to do it for Eclipse legal reasons.

OK, did it work for M1? If yes, I'll try to merge it into the master branch.

title: NA
body:
> > Alexander, thanks! I cannot create the pull request for you. You have to do it for Eclipse legal reasons.
> 
> OK, did it work for M1? If yes, I'll try to merge it into the master branch.

IDK! I do not have access to an ARM mac. Someone else will have to test, but at least we can build a product. I already created a PR. I could do it from your repo.

title: NA
body: @wimjongman, so you want me to merge both #348 and #353 ? Do we want to wait for someone to test it?

title: NA
body: No we have to wait for someone to test it. Are you a WB committer?

title: NA
body: @wimjongman, I'm one of the founders/creators of SWT Designer (which become WindowBuilder later) since 2003. And yes, I'm still a committer. :)

title: NA
body:
Hi Alexander. Thanks for rejoining us!! We can certainly use your help because the project has difficulty catching up with the latest Java/Eclipse changes. 

In this case, I suggest merging your changes so that we have a snapshot ready for people with access to an M1. WDYT?

title: NA
body: OK, I tested and fixed M1 support, it works fine for me now. Additionally, I added M1 support for text baseline alignment. See the screenshot. I'll merge the pull requests shortly.

title: NA
body: Thanks, Alexander!

title: Window Builder crashes when doing anything on the Design tab

### Discussed in https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/discussions/345
Originally posted by **tobieche110** October 25, 2022 Hi! So, I recently installed this plugin. I can't manage to get it to work. I can access the Design tab when I create an Application Window class, but if I try to do anything (inserting a button in the window, redimensioning it, anything) I get this error: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15698861/197889993-cf97727f-2a59-4084-89d0-f4fc0904b1e2.png) (This particularly happens when I try to redimension it) I've googled the issue a lot and I can't find any solution. At fist I thought it was an error from this specific project, but it happens even on fresh new projects without any other class. title: Force the WindowBuilder DesignComosite to use the Light theme
body:
Hello, 

I am trying to figure out a way to "force" DesignComposite composite to always use the Light theme (or better yet, the system theme) regardless to the Eclipse theme selection because the SWT "dark-mode" color defaults in the GEF canvas of WB are never correct in regards to how the SWT UI looks when build for production (using system theme).
Many times the SWT "dark-mode" color defaults in the GEF canvas of WB become so confusing that I result in setting widget colors statically and once I'm done with the SWT Composite design I remove the static colors one by one.

I tried to find a way to do this by poking around in the _org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.editor_.DesignComposite.java class,  but I cannot seem to find a way to "forcibly" set the widget colors defaults to Light or System theme defaults of the GEF canvas.

Do you know if this is actually possible?
If yes, the can you point to me which classes in the WB plugin sources should I be looking so that I can figure out some sort of a solution?
![wbtheme](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4510965/211045174-0724d91b-0498-414b-be81-9dfafcacaa6f.png)

title: NA
body:
There is currently work to enable dark styling of GEF, see https://github.com/eclipse/gef-classic/issues/128

It is better to invest into this issue, another issue would be that WB currently uses copies of GEF in its code, we should move WB to latest official GEF instead of using a custom copy.

cc @azoitl

title: When tab order set, new tabbable controls  not recognized
body:
If you set tab order on a form, then add a new control, tab order doesn't recognize it. You have to remove the tab order call in the code.
Either: when adding a control which can be tabbed to, if tab order is set add it to the end;
             - OR -
           when selected tab order, check if additional controls since it was last set, and add them.

Thanks.

title: NA
body: Fixed with #572. As you suggested, if a tab order has been set, any new controls will be automatically added to the end.

title: Unable to test WindowBuilder via RCPTT
body:
We integrated the WindowBuilder in our application and want to automatically test this functionality via RCPTT. However, it seems RCPTT is unable to pick up the GEF edit-parts. 

Let's consider the following example:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70652978/225895420-019a9052-9760-48ca-86cc-a30cad8dc82d.png)

If I click on the palette or the properties, nothing is recorded by RCPTT. Drag & Drop to the content pane is also ignored. The only thing that is detected are interactions with the components tree, given that this is an SWT component.

If I double-click on the pallete, following entry is recorded:

```
with [get-editor "JavaFrame.java" | get-canvas -index 4] {
    double-click
}
```

I can also double-click on other components, but the only thing changing here is the index. So it seems like RCPTT is able to detect the root part, but not the elements that are contained by it.

Our application also contains graphical editor, where we use GEF directly. Which we _are_ able to test via RCPTT. My suspicion is that something in the GEF/Draw2D fork, used by the WindowBuilder doesn't play nice with this tool.

Any thoughts?

title: NA
body: Yes, that could be the case. Are you able to dive in and figure out what is going on?

title: NA
body:
Yeah, I'm afraid I figured out what's going on here...

Normally, when you click on a GEF edit-part, RCPTT records something along the line of:
```
with [get-editor "JavaFrame.java" | get-diagram | get-edit-part -className ScrolledCompositeEditPart] {
    ....
}
```

The way this works is that if you click on a canvas, RCPTT checks whether this canvas is of type FigureCanvas. The same is true for the edit-parts. If this is the case, then those special `get-diagram` and `get-edit-part` statements are created.

Those classes also exist for the WindowBuilder. However, RCPTT expects them to be in the `org.eclipse.gef` package, but the classes it finds are in `org.eclipse.wb.gef` and therefore incompatible.

As far as I can tell, this leaves three options:
- Migrate WindowBuilder to the latest GEF-classic release
- Extend RCPTT to support the GEF fork used by WindowBuilder
- Accept that WindowBuilder can't be tested via RCPTT

Given that both the first and second option are far from trivial, my concern is that the third option is the most feasible one.
:-(

title: NA
body:
I assume RCPTT does something like class.getName().equals("org.eclipse.gef.FigureCanvas"); 

Could that not be easily generalized also to include WB?

title: NA
body:
> I assume RCPTT does something like class.getName().equals("org.eclipse.gef.FigureCanvas");

It's a little bit more compilcated than that. RCPTT has a set of [dedicated](https://github.com/eclipse/org.eclipse.rcptt/tree/master/runtime/tesla/org.eclipse.rcptt.tesla.recording.gef) GEF plugins. First it checks via an `instanceof`, whether the object is of the correct type and then it retrieves the internal state, either via getter methods or via reflection.

Which means even if it receives a WB FigureCanvas, we wouldn't get very far because e.g. the private fields don't match. But it might be possible to generalize this via the Eclipse [adapters](https://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-Adapters/index.html). So instead of doing the `instanceof` check, RCPTT calls `Adapters.adapt(object, FigureCanvas.class)`.

Because the object already has the correct type for GEF figures, it should remain compatible with the previous implementation. The only thing left is for either us or WB to define translation rules to convert the WB figures into GEF figures. Though I can't predict how difficult such a conversion would be.

title: NA
body: With the revival of the [GEF](https://github.com/eclipse/gef-classic) project it is desired to move WB to the latest GEF anyway. @ptziegler maybe it is as easy as adjusting the MANIFEST dependencies and using search and replace. Did you try this? If anything is needed in GEF to support WBs fork, I would be fine to add it to GEF.

title: XWT Plugin incompatible with latest Eclipse platform
body:
WB uses the seemingly custom Eclipse plugin org.eclipse.e4.xwt as an embedded jar. This plugin is not compatible with the latest version, given that it still uses classes such as SWTObservables, which were removed with
https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.ui/commit/c44f8d77f42cbcc17a0da3daabbb16bcd8745a86

Because WB uses the compiled classes, this problem only shows up at runtime (such as the XWT tests). The options are to:

- Recompile the jar against the Eclipse and fix any dependency issues.
- Get the plugin into the Eclipse platform.

title: NA
body:
If that is the case and nobody complained about this, I would think that the active user base of XWT and WB is very small and would suggest to retire XWT support. If someone shows up to enable XWT again, this person  could revert the removal and make XWT support work again.

@ptziegler WDYT?

title: NA
body: Fine for me too !

title: NA
body:
No objections from my side, either. We only use the Swing builder, so it doesn't affect us.

I only noticed it after checking the tests, because it's not even possible to open the design page of an XWT application, without running into a NoClassDefFoundError caused by a reference to the TableTree widget.

Which means that the user base is either still running an older Eclipse version or already found a way around this problem.

title: NA
NA
body:
Given that it was relatively straightforward to integrate the latest XWT release, I considered better to keep supporting XWT. All the noticeable incompatibilities with recent Eclipse versions have been resolved.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/77af3e1b-a7d9-461d-a69a-25b5a27e742b)

title: NA
body: I'm sure someone will be thankful, but they'll likely forget to thank you!

title: Update WB to Java 17
body:
Platform and multiple other projects moving to Java 17 as minimum.

Shall we do the same for WB? cc @ptziegler @lcaron @wimjongman

title: NA
body: I can work on the topic this week end

title: NA
body: Sounds good to me. As far as I know, the active support for Java 11 is supposed to end with the release of the new LTS, Java 21, sometime around September this year. So we might as well get ahead of the curve.

title: Failing test cases on Linux builds.
body: There are currently ~150 test cases, which are failing on the Linux builds. We should temporarily disable them, until all fixes which are part of #363 have been merged.

title: NA
body:
> until all fixes which are part of https://github.com/eclipse/windowbuilder/pull/363 have been merged.

Will this fix the tests as well? I though 363 is only about the correct upload of the test results? Sorry for not having a lot of time to investigate the issues, I'm flipping between multiple repos and build jobs today so I might miss things which are clear to you.

title: NA
body:
That was the initial plan. But I've "misused" it to keep track and repair all failing test cases, which is why it currently contains 10 commits, instead of just 1.

I think I'll do the following:
- preserve the current state of the branch and roll back anything unrelated to the yaml script
- temporarily disable the failing test cases
- adapt the existing pull-request to also reactivate the tests they repair
- create pull requests for the remaining test cases

title: NA
NA
body: Sounds good to me.

title: NA
body:
The last failing test case has been fixed with 37ee1e3b6d55a1634ccdcae28a14cbac81d1b6d2.
With the exception of some sporadic errors, all tests should be green, on both Windows and Linux.

title: NA
body:
Hm... did you execute the tests on the master? I sadly wasn't able to finish my tests, so I haven't merged the development branch yet.

The crash report should also contain a stack frame. Can you upload that as well? The new implementation uses SWT to take the screenshot. If the error occurs there, I can try to create a reproducer and forward it to their development team.

Can you also try to just execute the AbsoluteLayoutSelectionActionsTest (the SWT one, not the Swing one)? That one should be enough to reliably reproduce the SIGSEGV. So you don't have to always execute the entire test suite.

title: NA
body:
I've ran the test suite on KDE Wayland and so far, the crash didn't show up again. While I had 5 screen-resolution-specific test failures, the entire build finished.

In short, the problem seems to stem from taking a screenshot widgets which are only partially visible. Meaning the current solution is to crop the screenshot to ignore the unmapped area.
One example being the AbsoluteLayoutSelectionActionsTest, which used to consistently crash on Wayland.

I've moved a lot of the screenshot-logic from C to Java. So if a similar problem happens in the future, we hopefully have an easier time debugging this problem. I've also switched to taking the screenshot via SWT, rather than calling the Cairo methods directly. Reason being that they certainly have more experience dealing with GTK/GDK than I do.

As a side note: Even though the tests should finish, this doesn't mean the SWT editor is usable on Wayland. There is a general problem on Wayland, where any screenshot is just white. The same problem also happens with a pure SWT application and existed prior to this change.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/0b955d29-2e18-4173-8e32-2fbb28adda4a)

Please re-open this bug if this problem continues to exist.

title: Inconsistent formatter settings in WB projects
body:
Something quite frustrating when working with the WB code is that most of the code is formatted using spaces with an identation depth of 2. _However_, the project-specific settings are configured to use tabs with an identation depth of 4.
So whenever I modify the code, I have to double-check that the auto-formatting doesn't break the code style.

From the project settings of WB Core:
> org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.tabulation.char=tab
> org.eclipse.jdt.core.formatter.tabulation.size=4

For the sake of compatibility, we should adapt the project-specific settings to match the actual code style. If we ever happen to create new plugins, those should then follow the built-in Eclipse profile.

I would suggest moving everything to the standard Eclipse formatter (I did
this in the past for some code) and use the cleanup batch operations to

ago.

Git can ignore whitespace changes, so we should be fine to still see the
commit history.

title: Remove usage of Applet/JAppelt and AppletInfo
body:
The Applet/JApplet class has been marked as deprecated back in Java 9 and marked for removal in Java 17. Given that most browsers dropped their support for Java plugins, we should remove the corresponding code from WB.

See [JEP 398](https://openjdk.org/jeps/398) for reference.

From the original Oracle whitepaper:

> With modern browser vendors working to restrict or reduce the support of plugins like Flash, Silverlight and Java in their products, developers of applications that rely on the Java browser plugin need to consider alternative options. Java developers currently relying on browser plugins should consider migrating from Java Applets to the plugin-free Java Web Start technology.
>
> Supporting Java in browsers is only possible for as long as browser vendors are committed to supporting standards based plugins. By late 2015, many browser vendors had either removed or announced timelines for the removal of standards based plugin support, while some are introducing proprietary browser-specific extension APIs. Consequently, Oracle is planning to deprecate the Java browser plugin in JDK 9.
>
> The deprecated plugin technology will be completely removed from the Oracle Java Development Kit (JDK) and Java Runtime Environment (JRE) in a future Java release TBD. Java Web Start applications do not rely on a browser plugin and will not be affected by these changes.

title: NA
body: +1, please provide PR

title: NA
body: 👍 for me too

title: NA
body:
I would not consider removing Applet support until at least December 2030.  Java 8 supports applets natively and via JNLP.  Applets can still be run in the IE 11 browser via Edge and IE compatibility mode.  Java 8's extended support ends December 2030.  See page https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/java-se-support-roadmap.html for details.  Although the browser Java Plugin is no longer formally supported, JNLP (aka Java web start) is until December 2030.  Applets can be deployed through JNLP. 
Webswing supports applets, too, which further bolsters their viability.

title: NA
body:
If part of the user base is still using Applets, then I'm content with keeping them for as long as long as they are functional.

But I don't know how realistic it is, to keep supporting them until 2030. The final decision will probably be made by Oracle, when they decide to remove those classes from the JDK.

They still seem to be contained in the upcoming Java 21, but once they are gone, I'm leaning towards keeping WB compatible with the latest Java version, rather than trying to keep Applets alive... But I suppose that's something that can be discussed again, when that time has come.

title: What is the maximum width and height of JFrame In design window?
body:
What is the maximum width and height of JFrame in design window?
I drag the mouse to change the width and height of JFrame to 4096x2048. The width and height of JFrame will automatically change back to 30xx * 18xx after draging.

Is this a bug?

title: NA
body:
That sounds definitely like a bug. In principle, there should be no hard limit on how big the frame can be.

I've created a simple class using the JFrame template and if I extend the frame horizontally, I can change the width arbitrarily. Just when I try to do the same vertically, the frame snaps back to the height of the client area.

Even if I change the height in the source page, the value is not taken over when switching back to the design page.

title: [GTK] Widgets are drawn with empty bounds
body:
Related to some of our test failures, some of the widgets are drawn with zero width and height.

Let's illustrate it via the following Nebula [example](https://github.com/eclipse/nebula/blob/master/examples/org.eclipse.nebula.snippets/src/org/eclipse/nebula/snippets/collapsiblebuttons/CollapsibleButtonsSnippet1.java).

If you launch this example as a normal Java application, you get the following shell:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70652978/231844116-fc461c40-b15d-41fd-9c1b-bd5d0ef3375a.png)

If you open the same class with the WindowBuilder, both in the design page, and the preview, you get the following shell:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70652978/231844378-f535abf8-63f8-4205-bbb5-fe56a7f3a458.png)

title: NA
body:
I had a look again and it seems like WindowBuilder generally can't handle for-loops (or loops in general). Which makes sense, given that we perform a static analysis of the Java code.

If I take the mentioned example and unroll the loop, the widget is shown correctly. It _might_ be possible to implement this functionality, though I don't believe this has a high priority at the current time.

title: Jenkins Test Failure in Menu Complex Test
body:
There are currently 2 test failures in our Jenkins builds, which don't show up when executed locally/on GitHub:

```
Results:

Failures: 
  MenuComplexTest>DesignerTestCase.runBare:164->tearDown:59->DesignerEditorTestCase.tearDown:92->DesignerTestCase.assertNoLoggedExceptions:239 Check console for logged exceptions. expected:<0> but was:<1>
Errors: 
  MenuComplexTest>DesignerTestCase.runBare:164->DesignerTestCase.runTest:175->test_deleteBarWithSubmenu:462->RcpGefTest.openComposite:52->RcpGefTest.openJavaInfo:58->AbstractJavaProjectTest.createModelCompilationUnit:250 » JavaModel

Tests run: 7130, Failures: 1, Errors: 1, Skipped: 0
```

The second failure indirectly caused by the first one, because the previous workspace is not cleaned up properly. After a lot of debugging, it became clear that the problem seems to be the screen resolution on the Jenkins node.

To reproduce:
- Go to PropertyTable -> drawContent()
- Comment out the following check:
```
// stop, if already invisible
if (y > clientArea.height) {
	break;
}
```
- Execute MenuComplexTest -> test_deleteItemWithSubmenu()

title: NA
body:
The problem is that the property table is redrawn while WB is still deleting the widget. So we're at a state where the widget has already been removed from the databinding but is still registered as selected. When we then try to redraw the table, we attempt to fetch the no-longer-existing databinding for the widget.

In short, instead of:

- Update Databinding
- Update Selection
- Redraw

We do:

- Update Databinding
- Redraw <- Error
- Update Selection

The reason this problem doesn't happen locally is because the table is just too small. So the problematic property is outside of the visible area, thus it isn't redrawn.

title: NA
body:
The structure is analogous to this once the first release is published:

- https://download.eclipse.org/modeling/emf/emf/builds/release/latest
- https://download.eclipse.org/modeling/emf/emf/builds/milestone/latest
- https://download.eclipse.org/modeling/emf/emf/builds/nightly/latest

These are automatically kept up to date as builds are published.   If you have some existing location that you'd like to keep, you can always make that location a composite that points at one of these new locations.   The nightly repos are limited in number and old repos cleaned up automatically.  The milestone build repos are cleaned up once a new version starts; the version is derived from the/a feature's version.  The release repos are version numbered and are retained permanently.

I'll write some more centralized documentation once we get this in place...

> And that thing is old as the hills, not having produced something new since 2011:

It really is... Even though their GitHub page is still somewhat maintained, the last issue was fixed back in 2020. In any case, that's not a can of worms I want to open so soon after the ByteBuddy migration.

https://github.com/apache/commons-digester

Given that the dependency to CGLib was introduced with Digester 3.2, my current idea is to build WB against the 3.1. Without an upper bound in the Manifest files, users are free to install a newer version, if they want. But then _they_ have to contribute the CGLib bundle.

Which then leads to the next problem, which is that EasyMock _also_ has a dependency on CGLib. So I have to see whether we can update the embedded jar to a newer version or switch to Mockito there as well.

In short, not something that's done by the upcoming milestone... :sweat_smile:

> Unfortunately the builds just seem to hang producing endless entries like this in the log:
> 
> ```
> (SWT:1599): Gdk-WARNING **: 06:03:03.119: A paint operation on the window is alredy in progress. This is not allowed.

This warning is thrown whenever one of our tests is calling getImageSurface() in native code (i.e. the `rcp.c`). The fact that it is shown over and over again seems to indicate that the tests are still running, it's just not shown in the log.

As a dirty workaround, could you try to increase the timeout in the `org.eclipse.wb.tests/pom.xml` file? It's currently set to 1h. If it's just the tests taking a long time, perhaps we can increase it a little until we figure out what's wrong.

I think that's "normal" behavior, because we're using a deprecated Cairo API. As I mentioned earlier, the warning is shown whenever we create a snapshot. So effectively once for each and every SWT/RCP test.
It would probably be clearer if JUnit would also log, which test it's currently executing...

> Now the build is finished in 37 minutes. What to conclude from that? 😱

Hm... So there really is something slowing down the tests every now and then.
In general, we should probably increase the timeout on the Jenkins job, given how tight the limit seems to be.

I also had a look at the profiler results this morning, and I think I missed a few optimizations which should shave off a couple of minutes when running the tests.

body:
> I think such packages can be marked x-internal. I'm not sure if using x-friends implies that it's internal too, e.g.,
> No doubt if you do that now, the tools will complain that you've removed API and must do a major version increment...

As far as I can tell, Tycho internally calls the bnd-baseline-plugin, which supports the exclusion of specific packages. The documentation even contains a similar example:

> For example, you want to match all implementation packages (i.e. they have impl in their name) except when they start with com.example. This can be achieved with:
>!com.example.*impl*, *.impl.*

But I think I just have to take some time and see how this works, exactly. In any case, for the next build, I think it's the most effective if I increase the micro version of all bundles, without using any baseline check.

As far as I can tell, the public API hasn't changed and every bundle has been affected by the Java 17 update.

body:

title: NA
body:
Hm... The exception seems to be thrown by the JavaInfoParser, whenever the Java version used to run the Eclipse is older than the Java version specified in the project, indicated by the _org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.compliance_ property.

Though I have no clue why it thinks you're using Java "0".
I wonder... we get the current Java version via SystemUtils.JAVA_VERSION_FLOAT which itself is derived from the "java.version" system property.
What Java version are you using?

title: NA
body:
@wimjongman Does this issue still show up with the 1.13 milestone? If so, can you check what your `java.version` system property is set to? We internally check the version via this method in commons-lang. Zero is defined as the error value: ``` /** *

* Gets the Java version as a float. *

* *

* Example return values: *

*
    *
  • 1.2f for Java 1.2 *
  • 1.31f for Java 1.3.1 *
* *

* The field will return zero if {@link #JAVA_VERSION} is null. *

* * @since 2.0 */ public static final float JAVA_VERSION_FLOAT = getJavaVersionAsFloat(); ```

title: NA
