title: disappering butttons
NA
body:
> Here is my issue. I have a frame with label, jtextfield, and 2 buttons when you run the program the label and the textfield show but the butttons dont until you mouse over them.

I don't think that's necessarily a WindowBuilder bug but just how Swing behaves. The primary issues seems to be that you call `frame.setVisible(true)`, _before_ adding the buttons. Because you also don't use a layout, there is no incentive for Swing to redraw the button area. That is until you hover over them.

In short, there are two ways to fix this:
- Call `frame.setVisible(true);` at the _end_ of the method, once everything has been added.
- Use something like GridLayout, FlowLayout.

The latter one is the more elegant and also more stable solution.

> When i try to run the Scientific Caalculator it has the messages the"cannot refer to nonfinal verible in scope.

That's sadly not something I could reproduce with the code snippet you provided. Which version of WindowBuilder are you using? Almost any newer version should require at least Java 11, so I find it odd that you mention Java 8.

title: Long test execution times after Eclipse 2023-06 update
body:
Our test runs frequently take ~1h to complete, rather than the "normal" 35min. Some even hit the timeout after 1h30min. See [here](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/actions/runs/5283488903/jobs/9559799595) as an example.

In the past, he occasionally had this problem while testing against the previous (2022-09) version, but I have the impression this problem got worse after the update.

Given that the jobs usually run slower on Windows than on Linux, that's where we should start looking.

title: NA
body:
Looking at [this](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/actions/runs/5293487420/jobs/9581676877) job, the entire build took 1h6min, but only 33min were spent on running the test.

Meaning an additional 33min was spent just on loading the target platform and compiling the code. Running the job locally, I'm pretty sure the release update site is the main problem. I think that also explains why those builds sporadically run into a timeout.

```
Warning:  Some attempts to read artifact osgi.bundle,org.eclipse.core.resources,3.19.0.v20230510-1240 failed:

Warning:        Retry another mirror:
Warning:           download from https://espejito.fder.edu.uy/eclipse/releases/2023-06/202306141000/plugins/org.eclipse.core.resources_3.19.0.v20230510-1240.jar failed
```

title: NA
body: And the fallback mirror is painfully slow... Which is why the download only takes forever.

title: NA
body: I've had this happen on the BIRT builds where one mirror it was using was extremely slow and it used that mirror to get the JustJ JRE such that the one file transfer took almost 1/2 hour.  The next day the problem didn't happen anymore.

title: NA
body:
Hm... I also got the same, slow resolution time after I went back to the 2022-09 target-platform definition, so this really seems to be the case.

Despite that, if I run the builds in short succession, once with Tycho 3 and once with Tycho 4, the latter is significantly faster. The last Jenkins build only took [26min](https://ci.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/job/build/job/PR-483/2/), so I assume they made several performance improvements since the previous release.

title: NA
body:
I think this is resolved with #483. Whenever I noticed those long target-platform resolution times, I switched over to the Tycho 4 branch and immediately noticed major performance improvements. In the end, I think its an accumulation of improvements that make the upcoming version much more efficient.

I also think the current nightly builds are stable enough that we can use them for the nightly builds.

title: NA
body: The platform itself uses 4.0 and I use that in many builds too. So I think it’s a fine decision.

title: Synchronize the SwtResourceManager with the JFace ResourceManager
body:
There is quite a lot of overlap between both classes. We should try to extend the JFace class in order to reduce the amount of duplicate code.

Following methods should be compatible: 
`getColor(int)` -> `Display.getSystemColor(int)`
`getColor(int, int, int)`, `getColor(RGB)` -> `createColor(ColorDescriptor)`
`getImage(int)` -> `Display.getSystemImage(int)`
`getImage(String)`, `getImage(Class<?>, String)`-> `createImage(ImageDescriptor)`
`getFont(...)` -> `createFont(FontDescriptor)`

The difficult method is going to be the `decorateImage()` method, which we use to quickly construct composite images. JFace doesn't provide a function for such a specific use-case.

title: NA
body:
As an alternative to the the `createX()` methods, depending on the use-case the `get` method could also be helpful. Then maybe https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.ui/pull/838 is also interesting for you.


> The difficult method is going to be the `decorateImage()` method, which we use to quickly construct composite images. JFace doesn't provide a function for such a specific use-case.

JFace also offers `org.eclipse.jface.viewers.DecorationOverlayIcon`, which seems to be capable of the same like `decorateImage()`. Since it is a ImageDescriptor it also works well with JFace' ResourceManager and one is not forced to really create the images immediately.
See for example https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.ui/pull/842.

Furthermore I wonder why there is a split of a custom `ResourceManager` and `SwtResourceManager`? To me it even looks like they share a lot of code.

title: NA
body:
Thanks for the suggestion. Though I fear the descriptors create another problem:
Quite often, WindowBuilder is using the images directly, which also often leads to memory leaks like in #260. Meaning before we can think about deprecating the SwtResourceManager, we first have adapt all (relevant) methods to use ImageDescriptors instead.

> Furthermore I wonder why there is a split of a custom ResourceManager and SwtResourceManager? To me it even looks like they share a lot of code.

There are a couple of head-scratchers in this project. And while I can't say for certain why it was done like this, my best guess is "convenience". Instead of having to learn the JFace API, it's quicker to just re-implement the class with methods suited for this project.

title: NA
body:
> There are a couple of head-scratchers in this project. 

They are not only in this project. 😄
In general, since the code generated by this WindowBuilder is used and also read by many developers I think it would be good to use the latest and best practices in order to be a good role model for them and show them how to do things best.

Btw. using the `ResourceManager `hopefully becomes a bit simpler with changes like https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.ui/pull/838.

title: Data Bindings still uses SWTObservables and friends
body:
Trying to use the databinding feature fails with:

> Unable to parse source.
> WindowBuilder was not able to parse source org.eclipse.core.databinding.observable.Realm.runWithDefault(org.eclipse.jface.databinding.swt.SWTObservables.getRealm(display), new java.lang.Runnable() { public void run() { } });. 
> line: 19 org.eclipse.jface.databinding.swt.SWTObservables cannot be resolved to a type

The SWTObservable class has been removed with the [4.25](https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.ui/commit/c44f8d77f42cbcc17a0da3daabbb16bcd8745a86). We have to use the new API instead (e.g. DisplayRealm.getRealm() instead of SWTObservables.getRealm()).

To reproduce:

- Create a new Shell.
- Open design page
- Add e.g. a background binding to the Shell component

title: Remove support for the deleted Databinding API
body:
Related to #491. There are several locations where WindowBuilder:

a) Makes several case-distinctions between the old and new Observable API
b) Creates a bi-directional mapping between methods of the new API to the old API

Keeping the former is a real pain in terms of maintainability. Latter falls apart because both versions are not 100% compatible.
Example: `SWTObservables.observeSelection()` can be any of `WidgetProperties.widgetSelection()`, `WidgetProperties.dateTimeSelection()`, ...
And this problem will only increase, the more features are added to the new API.

Given that the old API is gone for good, I don't think it makes any sense for WindowBuilder to keep referencing it internally or even generate code for it.

title: NA
body: I agree. Support can be dropped for the old binding classes.

title: Migration guide for code coming from ancient WindowBuilder Pro?
body:
We have an old customer coming back to us.

Almost 20 years ago, we delivered a project which included Swing screens using a set of custom components.
When used in their current environment (Windows Server 2003 x86, JDK 1.7.0_90, Eclipse 3.3.1.1 and WindowBuilder Pro 6.4.1 (2007/08/13)), these design just fine.
However, they are trying to update their environments and go over to 64-bit, which means they also have to upgrade to a current WindowBuilder. This is causing design time problems for large screens. If we "downgrade" the screens to use plain Swing controls, the problem goes away, so it is likely a compatibility issue situated in our own components.

Is there a migration guide that describes things that need to be done differently in order to work with WindowBuilder compared to the ancient Pro version? 

# Issue Description

In WindowBuilder Pro, they have

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/13708975/eb969945-5635-46b9-89b6-62b484424a5e)

The screen is 90 lines high, so 1530 pixels (component/line height is fixed at 17 pixels).
The screen's vertical resolution is 1080 pixels.
All items are visible.


The same screen in the current environment (Windows Server 2019 x64, OpenJDK 17.0.6, Eclipse 2023-03 (4.27.0) and WindowBuilder 1.12.0) is not shown completely:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/13708975/e939323e-fa6d-486d-99a2-e203acb795cd)

Same size and resolution.
The first partially visible item is at 1055 pixels.
Given that the component height is fixed at 17 pixels, its lower edge should be at 1072 pixels.

If they reduce the vertical resolution to 1024, then the visibility is commensurately reduced:

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/13708975/6b1c4187-db5a-40b2-b128-8898999ebadd)

Note that they claim they already investigated the free WindowBuilder over a decade ago, and saw the same problem at that time, which is mainly why they did not switch. The x86->x64 push is now forcing their hand.

If there is no migration guide, and none of this rings a bell as a known issue, I can attach the source of the screen in question along with our component jar for further investigation.

title: NA
body: Yes, please add all the stuff, as small as possible, that shows us the situation.

title: NA
body:
I agree, a small reproducer is greatly appreciated.

Maybe as a general question: Does the problem also show up in the preview or is it only the design page, where the screen is partially shown?

title: NA
body:
That's quite an old version of WindowBuilder you're using. In short: It seems like the _com.google.guava_ plugin isn't available in your Eclipse installation.

Generally I'd suggest installing the latest release. The required plugins should automatically be installed as part of the update:
https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/release/latest/

Alternatively, it may also work if you manually install Guava from e.g. the Eclipse Orbit update site:
https://download.eclipse.org/tools/orbit/downloads/drops/R20230531010532/repository

As a side-note:
XWT doesn't work properly with the Eclipse 4.26 an onwards due to the removal of the deprecated Observable API and planned for removal in a future WindowBuilder version.

title: NA
body:
Hm. I had a look at the 1.7.x update site and I get the feeling the Manifest file for the XWT plugin is broken. But how were we then able to create a release?...

In any case, I think there is a dependency problem within the 1.7.x WindowBuilder release, which is why the XWT feature doesn't work. XWT is also no longer part of the 1.12 release, which is why you still carry the old plugins in your Eclipse installation, even after the update.

I suggest the following:
Remove the WindowBuilder feature/plugins from your Eclipse installation and install the previous 1.11 release:
https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/release/1.11.0
That is the last release that still supports XWT.

> File, New, Other, Window builder, application window.

If you just want to create a new application window, it might not even be necessary to install XWT support. As an alternative, it may also be sufficient if you simply do a clean install of WindowBuilder, but this time, without XWT.

If the problem still shows up afterwards, if would be great if you could also upload the Java file that's causing the crash.

body: Note that tomorrow (September 6th) is the last day for contributing.  Whatever you contribute ends up on the release train for 2023-09 (barring an emergency respin) so that contribution could be the release repository.  Of course the build promotion you use produces a release repository by copying/mirroring the most recent milestone build, so you should do a milestone build and then a release build.

title: NA
body:
> I'm a little confused because the release build still compiles & tests the latest commit: With the `release` build type, the build will simply ignore the local build artifacts?
> 
> > Note that a release build will not promote the build, but rather will promote the most recent milestone build.

Sorry yes it still does a full build but ignores the result artifacts completely.  A bit less than perfect but easier not to try to make the whole regular build be skipped for the 4 times per year that you could save that build time.

title: WindowBuilder class not found exception and solution
body:
I have an RCP application in which the WindowBuilder can be installed from the p2 Update Manager. Since one of the latest releases the builder is workin again after changes of some libraries (see [forum post](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/discussions/172)).

However when I opened a self created layout with two tabs and some components when I opened the second tab I received a class not found exception. Here the relevant part:

java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/mvel2/compiler/Accessor
	at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass1(Native Method)
	at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:1013)
	at java.base/java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:875)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.impl.asm.ASMAccessorOptimizer$ContextClassLoader.defineClass(ASMAccessorOptimizer.java:2321)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.impl.asm.ASMAccessorOptimizer.loadClass(ASMAccessorOptimizer.java:2332)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.impl.asm.ASMAccessorOptimizer._initializeAccessor(ASMAccessorOptimizer.java:814)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.impl.asm.ASMAccessorOptimizer.compileAccessor(ASMAccessorOptimizer.java:957)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.impl.asm.ASMAccessorOptimizer.optimizeAccessor(ASMAccessorOptimizer.java:345)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.dynamic.DynamicGetAccessor.optimize(DynamicGetAccessor.java:95)
	at org.mvel2.optimizers.dynamic.DynamicGetAccessor.getValue(DynamicGetAccessor.java:65)
	at org.mvel2.ast.ASTNode.getReducedValueAccelerated(ASTNode.java:108)
	at org.mvel2.ast.BinaryOperation.getReducedValueAccelerated(BinaryOperation.java:146)
	at org.mvel2.ast.And.getReducedValueAccelerated(And.java:34)
	at org.mvel2.compiler.ExecutableAccessor.getValue(ExecutableAccessor.java:38)
	at org.mvel2.ast.ReturnNode.getReducedValueAccelerated(ReturnNode.java:52)
	at org.mvel2.compiler.ExecutableAccessor.getValue(ExecutableAccessor.java:38)
	at org.mvel2.ast.IfNode.getReducedValueAccelerated(IfNode.java:74)
	at org.mvel2.MVELRuntime.execute(MVELRuntime.java:85)
	at org.mvel2.compiler.CompiledExpression.getDirectValue(CompiledExpression.java:115)
	at org.mvel2.compiler.CompiledExpression.getValue(CompiledExpression.java:111)
	at org.mvel2.MVEL.executeExpression(MVEL.java:985)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.model.util.ScriptUtils.evaluate(ScriptUtils.java:147)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.model.util.ScriptUtils.evaluate(ScriptUtils.java:86)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.swt.model.layout.LayoutDataInfo$6.isDefault(LayoutDataInfo.java:313)
	at org.eclipse.wb.internal.swt.model.layout.LayoutDataInfo$6.endEdit_aboutToRefresh(LayoutDataInfo.java:299)

From this error I deduced that mvel  was missing on the classpath. So I searched for this library and found it:

https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.mvel/mvel2/2.5.0.Final

I added it to the module classpath of my RCP (I have a bundled JDK) and the error was finally gone.

Could it be possible that this is a general missing WindowBuilder library?

title: NA
body:
Hm... I assume this is a side-effect of replacing the embedded MVEL jar with the official Maven release, which I did as part of be7cead7f5e9eeff112a3d35a5f9b947ba8fcc77. The new bundle should be part of the WindowBuilder installation, so normally, it shouldn't be necessary to explicitly add it to the classpath.

Can you provide a small reproducer so that I can test this further?

title: NA
body:
I stripped down a GUI which produces this exception in a regular Eclipse SWT project without any custom RCP app dependencies (see Java class attachment below as *.txt)
[_ModelGui.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12281522/_ModelGui.txt)

If you double click on the second tab the exception will be thrown.

If you delete line 473  `featureLabel.setLayoutData(new GridData(SWT.FILL, SWT.FILL, true, false, 2, 1));
` it will not throw the exception. 

Strangely it works also if you delete other GUI elements above.

I tested this in Eclipse on Windows 2023-03 with the latest WB release (1.13)

title: NA
body:
Awesome! Thank you a lot.

The exception seems to be thrown by MVEL while trying to load a certain "ASMAccessorImpl_\<random-integer\>", which  seems like an internal class created by MVEL itself. Furthermore, it's a lot harder to trigger this exception while debugging, so I'm suspecting timing and classloader loading/unloading within MVEL to be the primary factor.

A quick search lead me to https://github.com/mvel/mvel/issues/194, which seems to describe exactly what you're experiencing. Sadly, without any result. I find it weird that the problem no longer showed up after you added MVEL to the classpath, but that might've simply tweaked the timing in a favorable behavior.

The issue was reported with MVEL 2.4.3. Over the next few days, I'll try to see if it also shows up with an older versions. Alternatively, I can also try to synchronize calls to MVEL. But right now, I know too little about this library to say for certain what's causing this :(

title: NA
body: Great. I have to thank for looking into this.

title: NA
body:
Fixed with #534 
It seems like my initial guess was wrong. MVEL internally loads an instance of Accessor using a different classloader than what's used to call it. This classloader is based on the project classloader and thus doesn't have MVEL in its classpath, hence the exception.
Which means your initial guess was correct and also the reason why manually adding it to the classpath resolves the problem.
The problematic part of the code is only called occasionally, for reasons that I simply don't know. Which is also why I can't simplify your example any further and create an integration test for it. :/
In any case, the solution is the same as yours: To make sure MVEL is part of the project classloader.

title: NA
body: Top. Thanks for fixing this so fast!

title: WindowBuilder was not able to show the GUI
body:
I upgraded from Eclipse Neon which was not having any problems to Eclipse 2023-06.  Since then, I have issues when using GridBagLayout.  Every time I use the Pallet to drop a component onto my JPanel.  If I try to change a label text or rename a component I get errors.

I added a new label and tried to set the text and got this error.
Internal Error
WindowBuilder encountered unexpected internal error. 
This could be caused by a WindowBuilder bug or by a misconfiguration issue, conflict, partialupdate, etc.
org.eclipse.wb.internal.core.utils.check.AssertionFailedException: assertion failed

If I try to Delete Contents of a row or Delete Row I get this error
Internal Error
WindowBuilder encountered unexpected internal error. 
This could be caused by a WindowBuilder bug or by a misconfiguration issue, conflict, partialupdate, etc.
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException: Index: 1, Length: 0

I have tried to update WindowBuilder and check all plugins and settings I can think of.

Can anyone offer any suggestions on resolving this issue?
[Eclipse_WindowBuilder_bugs.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12302695/Eclipse_WindowBuilder_bugs.txt)

title: NA
body:
I remember seeing a similar error a few months ago, but I was never able to reliably reproduce it. Would it be possible for you to provide a small example? I've just created a simple panel and there drag & drop works with the GridBagLayout, so I assume it only shows up under certain circumstances.

Which WindowBuilder version did you upgrade from?

title: NA
body:
Hold on... you're using an _actual_ Java 8? 

That explains a lot. And if I switch to such an old Java version, I get exactly the same error... Internally, we're using the native Eclipse compiler to process the Java code, which is build (and tested) against Java 17.
My guess is that this is an incompatibility that was introduced at some point during their development cycle. And given that this doesn't show up with newer versions, not something that is likely to get fixed.

> because I need to build with 1.8.0

I think it's just not possible anymore to run recent versions WindowBuilder with Java 8, meaning you need to migrate to a newer Java version, if you want to use it.

If you _need_ to run the code with Java 8, then you could instead set the compiler compliance of your Eclipse project to 1.8. The resulting code should then still be executable with Java 8, even though it was compiled with a newer version.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/7d526468-b3a0-4b4e-b132-6d477f95b7e7)

title: WindowBuilder fails to install for basic Java IDE via dropins
body:
I know the use of dropins folder is not very popular nowadays, but i tend to use it because it provides a fast systemwide install using scripts. I have used this procedure for eclipse Java IDE with WindowBuilder, but it's failing since eclipse 2023-06 with WindowBuilder 12. Actually, it does behave as usual with eclipse JEE 2023-06!

I'm using both W10 and Linux Ubuntu 22.04, properly updated. Neither the OS nor the JDK version (adoptium) seem to make any difference.

The procedure:
- Unzip/untar eclipse.
- Create dir dropins/WindowBuilder and unzip WindowBuilder-Updates-1.12.0.zip
- Remove p2 root files in dropins/WindowBuilder
- Start eclipse (removed .eclipse and .p2 for testing purposes)
- Check for WB icon / Check with New XXX wizards for WindowBuilder
- Maybe restart eclipse and retry: makes no difference

As I said:
- Java IDE 2023-03 + WB 11: OK
- Java IDE 2023-06 + WB 12: fail
- JEE IDE 2023-06 + WB 12: OK

Last week I also tried with Java IDE 2023-09 M2, with no luck.

I have copied config listings before and after populating the dropins folder in both cases. I may keep using eclipse JEE, but I hope this may help.

David
[eclipse202306jee.conf-000.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12344294/eclipse202306jee.conf-000.txt)
[eclipse202306jee.conf-dropins.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12344296/eclipse202306jee.conf-dropins.txt)
[eclipse202306.conf-000.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12344299/eclipse202306.conf-000.txt)
[eclipse202306.conf-dropins.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12344300/eclipse202306.conf-dropins.txt)

title: NA
body:
I've just tried to start both WB 11 and 12 via dropins and with the Eclipse 2023-09 M1, but neither works. So I find it weird that it did with the 2023-03.
I also have the suspicion that this is a general issue in Equinox/P2 because when I look at the log, I can see following error being thrown several times (and the same with 1.12.0, of course):
> Error: file:/home/patrick/eclipse/dropins/WindowBuilder-Updates-1.11.0/ is not a valid extension location because it already contains a standard p2 repository file.

If you remove everything but the features and plugins folder, the dropin mechanism seems to work again. So I think that problem is not exclusive to WindowBuilder.

Can you try and run `./eclipse -clean -consoleLog` via the command line to see if you get the same error?

title: NA
body:
That's right. I have always got that "contains p2 file" error if I don't remove the extra files from the root of the WB updates ZIP. In all cases I ALWAYS removed them; the problem is NOT about that. It might be handy to have a separate distributed file without them, but myself I really don't care much about it.


OK, let's try: M1 or M2?… I suppose you tried "eclipse Java IDE", not "eclipse JEE IDE"
No luck: no WB icon, no new WB wizard. ¿Did you really succeed?

See both setup log and config files:
[eclipse202309M2.conf-dropins.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12346924/eclipse202309M2.conf-dropins.txt)
[eclipse202309M2.setuplog.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/12346925/eclipse202309M2.setuplog.txt)

Remember that I told you that the same procedure does work if using "eclipse JEE IDE 2023-06". Actually, to make me sure, I have just tried the exact same steps for "eclipse JEE IDE 2023-09 M2" and it works: both icon and WB wizard are visible there straight out of the box!

title: NA
body:
> Did you really succeed?

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/df2cf98c-bebf-4023-b1f2-2413ddb4f163)

Well, this one was with the 4.28, not the 4.29 M1. But I think I see what the problem is. Can you check something for me? Is `org.apache.commons.collections` installed in the JEE IDE? What about the normal IDE? 

What happens when you download `org.apache.commons.collections` from [Eclipse Orbit](https://download.eclipse.org/tools/orbit/downloads/drops/R20230531010532/) and also add it to the dropins folder?

title: NA
body:
It seems not…:

`
dmartin@ebano:~/tmp/borrar$ grep "org.apache.commons.collections" eclipse202306.conf-dropins.txt
dmartin@ebano:~/tmp/borrar$ grep "org.apache.commons.collections" eclipse202306jee.conf-dropins.txt
org.apache.commons.collections (3.2.2.v20220405-1659) "Apache Commons Collections" [Resolved]
Id: org.apache.commons.collections, Version: 3.2.2.v20220405-1659, Location: reference:file:plugins/org.apache.commons.collections_3.2.2.v20220405-1659.jar
`

And you're right 🙂: I repeated the same procedure with "Java IDE 2023-09 M2", I unjared org.apache.commons.collections_3.2.2.v20220405-1659.jar in a separate dropin's folder and voila! I got both the WB toolbar icon and the wizard; and I had no problems to create a new Java project, add an application window class and switch to see the design tab.

So, now… Should I patch my installation scripts or wait a bit for a fix in WB13?

title: NA
body:
> So, now… Should I patch my installation scripts or wait a bit for a fix in WB13?

As a temporary solution, I would go with manually adding the missing bundles. The fix itself shouldn't be too difficult. I just have to double-check if there are other dependencies that need to be added to the update site.

title: NA
body: Thanks a lot! It's been a nuisance these months, dealing with eclipse old, new, Java and JEE version swapping. Not to say all the testing time invested...  🤓

title: NA
body: It seems like only commons-collections was missing. The fix should be available with the next nightly build or the upcoming M3.

title: Issue with windowBuilder of Eclipse workspace
body:
![Capture](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/145546763/04f99e5a-d2e0-407c-a6f9-f84d758a9cd1)




How can i sold this issue?

title: NA
body:
Can you provide the source code of your Java class? As the error message says, your class doesn't seem to be a valid UI class, so WindowBuilder is unable to process it.

In general, I'd suggest creating the class using the "New" wizard and then add whatever UI components you need. 
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/22f9ea38-d573-4ba9-afe0-2ff0beaff26c)

title: NA
body: I assume those issues reported here are the result of compile errors in the Java source code. Most likely due to an incomplete module-info.java. With the upcoming 1.14.0, this file should be managed automatically, for the most part.

title: 1.14.0 Releng
body:
A document to catch releng issues for 1.14.0

- [x] Update version number and target platforms:
    - [x] Update the version number of all features to 1.14.0

title: NA
body:
MVEL doesn't support Java 21 and fails with a NoClassDefFoundError regarding java.lang.Compiler. See https://github.com/mvel/mvel/issues/328

This class was removed with Java 21: https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8205129

So it might be sufficient to update to just update to MVEL 2.5.0

title: NA
body: Fixed with #581. The fix will be available with the 1.14. For the time being, your best bet is to install the upcoming nightly build or to use an older Java version (17-20).

title: NA
body:
That class is marked for removal in Java 17.  Which JDK are you using?  

WindowBuilder is using the newest version of that library so this is not easily fixed with some update...

https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/mvel/mvel2/2.5.0.Final/

title: NA
body:
Do you mean java/lang/Compiler class?
java 21 2023-09-19 LTS

Do I understand correctly this is internal problem of WindowBuilder because of changes in JDK?
But why only in case of JTable? Rest of components work properly.

title: NA
body:
Workaround for this is running Eclipse with:

-vm
c:\Program Files\Java\jdk-17\bin\javaw

in eclipse.ini

title: NA
body:
This is a duplicate of #579 and has already been fixed with #581.

In short: The MVEL version distributed with current release (2.4.15) is not compatible with Java 21. So your options are to:
- Stay with Java 17 until the winter release
- Manually download and install MVEL 2.5.0
- Use the 1.14.0 M1: https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S20231002053

> That class is marked for removal in Java 17. Which JDK are you using?
> WindowBuilder is using the newest version of that library so this is not easily fixed with some update...

Only with the upcoming 1.14.0. The current release is still using the incompatible version.

> Do I understand correctly this is internal problem of WindowBuilder because of changes in JDK?
> But why only in case of JTable? Rest of components work properly.

MVEL is only used sporadically to evaluate the Java code. It's much more noticable with the SWT components.

title: NA
body:
Which update site are you using?
Which version of WindowBuilder are you trying to install?

Given that the Eclipse seems to be unable to find MVEL 2.5.0, I assume you're trying to install the 1.14.0 M1?
The bundle should be uploaded to this p2 repository here:  https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S202310020533
Can you give that one a go?

title: NA
body:
This is typically caused by p2 having some inconsistency between the content metadata (what installable units are available) and the artifact metadata (where is the jar associated with that unit).   A broken update site could cause that, but most often it's just some in-memory caching involved.  First try to restart the IDE and try again.  If the same problem happens,  try Window -> Preferences -> Oomph -> Bundle Pools -> Clear Cache...  That should force loading everything fresh directly from the internet...  The jar definitely exists at the above mentioned location:

https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S202310020533/plugins/org.mvel2_2.5.0.Final.jar

title: NA
body:
Maybe we should take one step back... What's the process with which you install WindowBuilder?

The normal workflow should be:

-> Help -> Install New Software...
-> Enter https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/release/1.13.0
-> Select all WindowBuilder features

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/b1f0ca1f-7812-4921-935c-fde3a3fbbd3f)

If that doesn't work, I'd consider cleanup up/disabling some of the p2 software sites. Perhaps a bad URL snuck its way in and is now causing problems.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/d90bfdb8-2253-4d6e-95d5-4cff55552890)

As a last option, I would suggest installing WindowBuilder in a fresh Eclipse environment.

title: NA
body:
I'm closing this one. As Ed mentioned, this issue is likely caused by an inconsistent cache and should be fixed by clearing the caches. In general, I can't reproduce this in a clean installation.

Feel free to reopen this issue if you think it is still relevant.

title: NA
body:
> Note I tried outputing the LAF as UIManager.put() calls, but WindowBuilder does not reflect this. Any other ways?

Just for clarification, you're talking about the LAF that's shown in the Design page, right? And from what it sounds like you're using Swing?

You should be able to add your own LookAndFeels.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/d0196dbf-4aa8-4222-a510-83687769d4ca)

As a quick test, I added the LookAndFeels from the latest Maven [jar](https://search.maven.org/artifact/com.formdev/flatlaf/3.2.1/jar) and it seems like the e.g. Darcula theme is working.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/ec8a94ac-3bca-4004-8cac-91914bf98fea)

title: NA
body:
> > Note I tried outputing the LAF as UIManager.put() calls, but WindowBuilder does not reflect this. Any other ways?
> 
> Just for clarification, you're talking about the LAF that's shown in the Design page, right? And from what it sounds like you're using Swing?
> 
> You should be able to add your own LookAndFeels.
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70652978/274407075-d0196dbf-4aa8-4222-a510-83687769d4ca.png)
> 
> As a quick test, I added the LookAndFeels from the latest Maven [jar](https://search.maven.org/artifact/com.formdev/flatlaf/3.2.1/jar) and it seems like the e.g. Darcula theme is working.
> 
> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70652978/274407766-ec8a94ac-3bca-4004-8cac-91914bf98fea.png)

Ah thanks, I didn't see that ability

title: help me
body: ![Screenshot (136)](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/147803521/defe6bf2-9455-473d-8bd3-576c6a60c025)

title: NA
body: You're using [Modules](https://dev.java/learn/modules/intro/). Either add "java.desktop" to your "module-info.java" or delete the file entirely.

title: NA
body:
I'm closing this issue, as it isn't an issue with WindowBuilder, but rather just the way modules work with Java 9 and onwards.

The comment above should be sufficient to resolve the compilation errors:

> You're using [Modules](https://dev.java/learn/modules/intro/). Either add "java.desktop" to your "module-info.java" or delete the file entirely.

> Exception java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: java/lang/Compiler

That looks a lot like you're using Java 21, which is only supported with the upcoming WindowBuilder version.
See: https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8205129

Right now, your only options are to either remain at Java 17 or to upgrade to the 1.14 M1:
https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S202310020533

I'm closing this one as a duplicate of #530

title: WB takes Desktop Background and display it in shell background
body:
Hello,

I am using Eclipse 4.19, JDK 21 on Ubuntu 23.04.
WindowBuilder 1.14.0 from https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S202310020533/

When I create a simple shell using WB it seems WB takes my Desktop Bakground and display it in design mode 

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/90908346/e218abc4-f150-462c-af46-ee1cc4c9ba4a)

Thanks in advance for your support.

title: NA
body:
Yeah... The screen capture on Linux is quite a pain. :/
What I think is happening is that the shell hasn't been rendered yet, by the time we try to capture it. As a result, we capture the area behind it (i.e. your desktop).

We have to do some funky stuff in order to capture shells. Does this problem also happen for other composites/widgets?

title: NA
body:
Yes it happens also for composites.
Just as a comment: this happens since 1.14, it did not happens with the previous versions.

title: NA
body: Similar issue here with WindowBuilder Current from the Marketplace. Any quick workaround?

title: NA
body:
I've cleaned up the snapshot mechanism to partially revert to the old logic (drawing via Cairo directly, rather than SWT), meaning it should behave the same way it used to in older version.

One caveat is that we no longer attempt to capture the window decorations, as they are not part of the shell itself. With X11, this is partially possible but not on Wayland, given the sever limitations when it comes to screen captures.

If you want, you can try it out with the latest milestone build:
https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S202311141707

I've closed the bug for now. Feel free to re-open it, if it still shows up with the upcoming release.

title: NA
body:
>  ALL of the imports have the error "The type is not accessible"

Are you using Java [modules](https://www.oracle.com/corporate/features/understanding-java-9-modules.html) by any chance?

I.e. does your project contain a module-info.java:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/4866a21b-ae17-47f4-b1b5-c3572d2705f1)

If so, you either have to adapt this file to require the SWT bundle or instead simply delete it.

title: NA
body: Wow - I deleted the module-info.java and it fixed the problem. I'll have to look into module-info.java and figure out what it does :-). Thanks a lot for your quick help. This has been driving me crazy.

title: NA
body: I assume those issues reported here are the result of compile errors in the Java source code. Most likely due to an incomplete module-info.java. With the upcoming 1.14.0, this file should be managed automatically, for the most part.

title: NA
body:
Actually, someone on this list solved it right away. The 2023-09 version started generating a "module-info" file by default. Defining that file makes the programmer specify any dependencies explicitly. The helpful suggestion was to delete the module-info file. Doing that made all the problems go away. 

I personally feel that it was a mistake to check the "module-info" option in the New Project form by default. It sure causes confusion for people like me who had no idea what the file does. I just assumed that it must be a good thing, since it was the default. I was wrong.

title: NA
body:
> I personally feel that it was a mistake to check the "module-info" option in the New Project form by default. It sure causes confusion for people like me who had no idea what the file does.

I agree, the modular system is quite obscure and the error message is not very helpful.. Hopefully, with the upcoming WindowBuilder version this will be something you no longer to worry about.

title: Double-clicking a WindowBuilder runnable jar gives JVM Launcher Error/Java Exception
body:
I have a Window Builder program (“WordleSolver”) that works when I run it within eclipse Version: 2023-09 (4.29.0) Build id: 20230907-1323. I believe that the project was originally created in a previous release.

I exported the program as a Runnable Jar.

THE PROBLEM:
Double-clicking on the runnable jar results in a Java Virtual Machine Launcher error dialog saying “A Java Exception has occurred”. I haven’t been able to figure out what the exception is or where it occurred.

NOTES:

The jar works fine when executed from the command line with “java -jar WordleSolver.jar”.
Command line Java version:
C:\Temp>java -version
java version "16" 2021-03-16
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 16+36-2231)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 16+36-2231, mixed mode, sharing)

When I exported it as a runnable jar, it gave me the seemingly ever-present “finished with warnings” message. Below  is the message with a summary of the details:
===========
JAR export finished with warnings. See details for additional information.
  Exported with compile warnings: WordleSolver/src/pkgWordleSolver/WordleSolverMain.java
JAR export finished with warnings. See details for additional information.
  Exported with compile warnings: WordleSolver/src/pkgWordleSolver/WordleSolverMain.java
  duplicate entry: .api_description
  duplicate entry: .api_description
  duplicate entry: about.html
  duplicate entry: about.html

Same “duplicate entry” message for the following IDs:
...
plugin.properties, about_files/LICENSE-2.0.txt, .api_description,  entry: .options,  about.html, plugin.properties, plugin.xml,   .api_description, .options, plugin.properties, plugin.xml,  .api_description, about.html, plugin.properties, .api_description, about.html, .api_description, .options, about.html, plugin.properties, .api_description, .options, about.html, plugin.properties, .api_description, .options, about.html, plugin.properties, plugin.xml, about.html, .api_description, .options, about.html, plugin.properties, plugin.xml
...
===========

The Build Path for the project is in the following screenshot.
Any ideas would be welcome.


![WordleSolver Build Path](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/147398075/dbc3fedc-a346-4d0e-b86b-b995ff136c5e)

title: NA
body:
> Double-clicking on the runnable jar results in a Java Virtual Machine Launcher error dialog saying “A Java Exception has occurred”. I haven’t been able to figure out what the exception is or where it occurred.

>The jar works fine when executed from the command line with “java -jar WordleSolver.jar”.

From what I can tell, the jar itself is valid, if you are able to launch it from the command line. My best guess is that the JDK that is used when double-clicking isn't the one that is used in the command line. That said, I fail to see how this is then related to WindowBuilder, given that the problem would show up on _any_ exported jar.

> When I exported it as a runnable jar, it gave me the seemingly ever-present “finished with warnings” message.
> duplicate entry: .api_description
> duplicate entry: .api_description
> duplicate entry: about.html
> duplicate entry: about.html

I would expect that to be normal. In the end, you create a runnable jar containing all required Eclipse dependencies. Meaning all bundles like e.g. JFace and SWT are merged into a single archive. If some of those bundles contain the same file (e.g. plugin.xml, license text), it's only natural that they overwrite each other.

title: NA
body:
I'm closing this one. The "duplicate entry" warnings are expected when shading multiple jars into one. If the same file is contained by multiple jars then one overwrites the other.

If the widget works fine inside the editor but not when exported, then this sounds unrelated to WindowBuilder and something that should be raised with the [PDE](https://github.com/eclipse-pde/eclipse.pde) project.

title: NA
body:
You're using Java 9 [modules](https://www.oracle.com/corporate/features/understanding-java-9-modules.html) without requiring `java.desktop`. This causes the compile errors in `Login_Page.java`, which is also the reason why WindowBuilder can't understand the code.

You either have to update your `module-info.java` accordingly or simply delete it, if you don't want to use modules.
I'm closing this issue as it this is normal Java behavior and not really related to WindowBuilder itself.

title: NA
body:
I see... that sounds like a duplicate of #499

In short: WindowBuilder was only partially updated

> java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList cannot be found by org.eclipse.wb.xwt_1.9.1.202203170939

As seen here, this is not the correct version.
To fix this, you need to do a clean re-installation of WindowBuilder.

1) In your menu bar, click on Help -> About Eclipse -> Installation Details
2) In the Installed Software tab, search for all WindowBuilder components and uninstall them
3) Reinstall WindowBuilder from the marketplace

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/ddbb8854-a7b0-480f-b606-e9b9462002f7)

title: Wayland support for SWT editor
body:
When trying to capture the shell and all its widgets with Wayland, the resulting images all end up completely empty.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/c718cf40-8851-455b-b675-a1d2ca009853)

This seems to be a [common](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/41560368/screenshot-comes-out-black-on-wayland) problem not only we, but also the SWT team seems to be affected by.

The most concise explanation I could find boils down to:
> By design, Wayland is a lot more secure than X11 and does not allow one application to capture the content of other applications

Or in short: Screen capture is not a valid use case.

Gnome seems to support using dbus API and some internal endpoints but that just reeks of bad code. Moreover, it would also mean that we have to implement this workaround for every window manager, which I don't see as a feasible solution...

Has anyone ever worked with Wayland or had to handle with this kind of problem? Suggestions would help out a lot!

My current plan is to invoke the capture mechanism from within the mocked shell (as in, the application tries to capture itself), but I have no clue if even that is allowed by Wayland...

title: NA
body:
There is a general problem with the combination of WindowBuilder, JDT and Java 8. Note that this problem doesn't occur with newer Java versions.

Personally, I don't think there is any point investigating this problem any further, given that Java 8 doesn't  even receive premium support anymore and given that several major projects moved to at least Java 11. So I don't think it's worth investigating what exactly goes wrong here.

I can only encourage you to give it a shot yourself, but if you _really_ need to build the project against Java 8, then I think your best shot is to use a modern JDK (effectively Java 21) while setting the execution environment of your project to Java 8. The result is that even though you're using a newer Java version, the generated byte code is still executable with a good ol' Java 8.

title: NA
body:
> There is a general problem with the combination of WindowBuilder, JDT and Java 8. Note that this problem doesn't occur with newer Java versions.
> 
> Personally, I don't think there is any point investigating this problem any further, given that Java 8 doesn't even receive premium support anymore and given that several major projects moved to at least Java 11. So I don't think it's worth investigating what exactly goes wrong here.
> 
> I can only encourage you to give it a shot yourself, but if you _really_ need to build the project against Java 8, then I think your best shot is to use a modern JDK (effectively Java 21) while setting the execution environment of your project to Java 8. The result is that even though you're using a newer Java version, the generated byte code is still executable with a good ol' Java 8.

So from what you tell me, Could I build the project with Java8, but using a more modern jdk, and would it work?

I don't know if this is exactly what you told me.

title: NA
body:
> I don't know if this is exactly what you told me.

This is exactly what I mean. If you right-click on your project and then go Properties -> Java Build Path -> Select JRE System Library -> Click Edit, you can select the execution environment for your project.

In the screenshot, I've set it to Java 8, even though I'm using Java 17. The generated byte code is still compatible with Java 8 and the compiler would even warn you, if you attempt to use any newer language features. There are a few caveats of course, but I don't think they should have a significant impact for WindowBuilder.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/c33a6f75-d234-4aad-bf40-ee4a84301a17)

title: Replace swing2swt BorderLayout with SWT BorderLayout
body: With 3.119, SWT implements a native BorderLayout. We should try to use this class directly, instead of the Swing port provided by the swing2swt.jar.

title: Remove dependency to Digester3
body:
We use this library to process the XML content of extension point contributions such as _wbp-factory.xml_ or _wbp-component.xml_ files.
However, this library hasn't been updated since 2011 and since then been succeeded by more modern (and better maintained frameworks such as [jaxb](https://github.com/eclipse-ee4j/jaxb-ri) or [FasterXML](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson). We should try to migrate to one of those frameworks, depending on what's already available on SimRel-Maven.

Getting rid of this library also allows us to remove the dependency to:
- commons-logging,
- commons-beantutils, 
- commons-collections (with the potential to update to commons-collections4)

title: NA
body:
The dependency to digester3, commons-collections, commons-logging and commons-lang is gone.

We now use JAXB, commons-collections4 and commons-lang3 instead 🎉

title: Default layout manager combo in Layouts Preference Page doesn't work
body:
Selecting any element in the default layout manager combo box always reverts back to the implicit layout. But this should only happen, if the element is unchecked in the table below.

What's happening is that we check, whether an element is checked, via a preference node. but unless the layout has been manually checked at least one, the corresponding node entry has never been initialized. Which is also why one can fix this problem by manually un-checking and re-checking all elements in the table.

https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/blob/3c7faebd77ed1f68c9d167a859fa3dda0ccb9cf2/org.eclipse.wb.core.ui/src/org/eclipse/wb/internal/core/preferences/LayoutsPreferencePage.java#L212-L216

Also from an UX perspective, why should unchecked elements show up in the combo box, if the user isn't allowed to select them?

This issue was introduced back with 280f8aa3282dce10f92e7d2cbe7077071aa11836.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/749ba5c8-19f5-4221-ab2d-801bdbbb2c01)

title: NA
body: Fixed with #641

title: Update screenshots/documentation in user guide
body:
While working on #640, I noticed that the interactive help is grossly outdated and needs to be updated. The screenshots are also really old, probably done with the Eclipse 3, perhaps even before that and occasionally show features that are no longer supported (e.g. GWT).

Someone has to take on the dreadful task of going through the HTML code to delete (or update) our documentation and ideally also take new screenshots. Perhaps something to consider for the next code freeze...

title: NA
body: I would recommend moving this to Asciidoc/ Markdown and generating a help page from this like Tycho or the Eclipse ui guidelines do

title: NA
body: Sounds like a good idea. Do you -by chance- made any good experiences with tools for converting our existing HTML documentation to AsciiDoc?

title: WindowBuilder development plugin should be installed as part of Oomph setup
body:
The plugin [org.eclipse.wb.dev](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/tree/master/org.eclipse.wb.dev) contains a custom builder and validator for the WindowBuilder xml files.

We should try to  re-enable this validation and have the plug-in be installed as part of the setup.
Right now, the only thing it does is causing the following warning:
> Unknown referenced nature: org.eclipse.wb.dev.wbNature

I assume the entry point for the Oomph script is the P2 Director, where we would have to add it as a new... project?
I don't see how the tool would be able to install the plug-in directly from the workspace, so I also believe that we need to publish it to our update site, together with the other artifacts, and then consume it from there...

In short, I need to read up on how Oomph actually works :sweat_smile:

title: NA
body: Yes we should publish it to the update site.  The rest is trivial.

title: NA
body: Fixed with #651. Both the WindowBuilder Dev plugin as well as SpotBugs are installed during the Oomph setup.

title: Future of the XWT WindowBuilder component
body:
It's that time again, I suppose... The issue was already brought up in the simrel-build repository when the XWT components were disabled from aggregation.

But this is not the topic of this issue. With the 2023-12 release, the Eclipse Platform moves from the javax.* to jakarta.* namespace, with the plan to drop the support of the former, at some point in the future. Unsurprisingly, XWT is still using the javax packages, which is already causing problems when trying to setup the WindowBuilder workspace.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/0cc09e24-5d99-4983-89b7-3ee1c5e5e3b4)

Given that both [this](https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/xwt/org.eclipse.xwt/+/205432) and [this](https://git.eclipse.org/r/c/xwt/org.eclipse.xwt/+/205609) item haven't been addressed yet, I don't have high expectation that this gets resolved anytime soon...

My position still hasn't changed where I'm willing to support XWT, as long as it doesn't require a significant amount of work. But given the direction their project is going, it might be worth to reconsider...

(Slightly unrelated, but I'm also curious what the GitLab migration plan for unmaintained projects is...)

title: NA
body:
> Java version 8 Update381

This is most likely the problem. I would suggest you use at least Java 17.
You can download a matching JDK from here: https://adoptium.net/

Note that Java 21 is also possible, but only with the latest WindowBuilder release.
If you still need to compile your project with Java 8, you can then simply set the execution environment to 1.8 in the project properties.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/9ad4b397-7435-4962-892c-80bbf9c49a5f)

title: DesignerException: 308 when setModel() of JTable
body:
Recently I've noticed such error when I try to set model of my table with custom one:
`private class CustomTableModel extends DefaultTableModel`

```
public MyOwnTable(Competition competition)
	{
		setCompetition(competition);
		setModel(new CustomTableModel());
		setDefaultRenderer(Object.class, new CustomTableRenderer());
		setTableProperties();
		setSorter();
	}
```

I see such error:
```
setModel(new CustomTableModel())

Exception during method invocation evaluation

An exception happened duringevaluation of

setModel(new CustomTableModel())
Method public void javax.swing.JTable.setModel(javax.swing.table.TableModel) was used with the parameters {<null>}. 
```

body:
Completion:
I don't know why this message happened, but after rebuild whole project I recieved new error which was connected with unitialized field. After placing it in `if` everything works like expected.
Anyway it reminds me another topic.
Is it possible to set some flag like 'lazy verification"? I mean quiet often I set a field but initialize it in constructor. It seems WindowsBuilder by default treat it like some kind of problem. Or maybe I understand this mechanism wrong?

title: NA
body:
It feels like something is missing here...

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/b6ee0e55-87e4-40df-accd-bf23101f5677)

Can you provide a minimal project that reproduces this problem?
What Java version are you using?
What WindowBuilder version are you using?

> Is it possible to set some flag like 'lazy verification"? I mean quiet often I set a field but initialize it in constructor. It seems WindowsBuilder by default treat it like some kind of problem. Or maybe I understand this mechanism wrong?

That shouldn't really be necessary. Internally, WindowBuilder creates stubs of all the classes that are used. Meaning that an error like this seems to indicate that something is going wrong somewhere.

body:
In general, there seems to be something wrong with your module-info.java. Which is why Java is unable to resolve the Swing classes.
Is there a reason why you have this file? If you don't want/need a modular project, you can simply remove those files.

The other problems are the compilation errors, which are already highlighted in the Java editor.

> i know eclipse is bottom of the barrel these days dont hate on me for using it

I mean.. unlike proprietary products, there is a very easy way to improve the IDE. But those are just my humble two cents.

title: WindowBuilder ScrollBar Bug
body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/discussions/695
Originally posted by **shadowxdgamer** January 25, 2024 There is a problem with WindowBuilder and it halted my work when ever i use the scroll bar to move around the mousedrag feature to drag elements or to resize them stops working well i can move them with the arrow keys that works but i can't resize Here is a video for better explanation : https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/64868173/97bdf880-3128-4500-96ea-7faf76f79fdf I'm using JDK17 and latest version of Eclipse is there a workaround to fix this? Thanks for answering

title: NA
body:
The problem seems to be that the drag start is never registered. Reason being that getStartLocation() contains the absolute coordinates of the mouse cursor, while getCurrentInput().getMouseLocation() contains the relative coordinates.

https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/blob/64f1703254067c6d3a44c7ac75fd5f6813e05b2e/org.eclipse.wb.core/src-gef/org/eclipse/wb/gef/core/tools/Tool.java#L241-L248

title: NA
body: Fixed with #699 . The fix will be part of the upcoming milestone.

Do you have a module-info.java file which is missing whatever module your custom JDateChooser is coming from? > > i added jcalender in module-info.java file, and it works fine You're likely using Java modules, so you either need to add `jcalendar` to your `module-info.java` file, or get rid of this file alltogether if you don't really need modules.

title: WindowBuilder unexplained bug
body:
For some reason after updating both my Eclipse and the WindowBuilder, it seems it struggles to move or resize components from my active project that made me a bit frustrated that I cannot proceed with its current situation.

In this video, I tried to recreate the bug by doing my project again from scratch and that JPanel added to the designer triggered the bug. Any idea what happened? I can recreate this bug across Windows, macOS, and Linux.


https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/65421364/1cfd5e2b-3d90-4657-b065-43b394f9aa5b

title: NA
body:
> A similar bug was reported via #695. Can you try out the latest milestone build? https://download.eclipse.org/windowbuilder/updates/milestone/S202401292103

So the bug was scrollbar related that prevents moving or resizing the components in the designer? That's something unexpected.

I tried your response and install the latest build of the WindowBuilder and it worked. Thank you for the update!


https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/65421364/3cfc7cbf-18c9-4609-a9aa-88a2a7b1f14f

title: NA
body:
> So the bug was scrollbar related that prevents moving or resizing the components in the designer? That's something unexpected.

That's correct. The offset from scrolling was ignored. It's something that can very easily be observed when scrolling only by a few pixels.
When clicking on an item, the box is then misplaced by the same amount by which you've scrolled.

The FocusTraversalOnArray was missing for Java 8 or higher and added with https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/commit/466ea6c7c5f946448030e2b2619b5d762e5056c1, as part of the 1.14.0 release.

title: Java version not recognized
body:
Opening WindowBuilder editor for a WB-designed file, I get the following message:

**Incompatible Java versions**
"Eclipse is running under 17.01, but this Java project has a 21 Java compliance level, so WindowBuilder will not be able to load classes from this project. Use a lower level of Java for the project, or run Eclipse using a newer Java version."

Java version (in Eclipse settings):  Java SE 21.0.2   -- NOT 17.01 !!
Environment description:  Java SE 21
Running under MacOS on Apple silicon

What accounts for this?  How can I fix this?

title: NA
body:
> Eclipse is running under 17.01, but this Java project has a 21 Java compliance level

What's the value of your `java.home` environment variable?
In the `Help` menu, click `About` -> `About Eclipse IDE` -> `Installation Details`

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/0368a7a4-93b2-45bf-b241-124ba6eb0fcc)

Next click on the Configuration tab and filter for `java.home`

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/67a37de1-e70b-4bd4-aa76-142bc80b246e)

According to the error message, this should be Java 17.

---

Alternatively, you can also change the execution environment of your WindowBuilder project to Java 17. Right-click on the project, click `Properties` -> `Java Build Path`. In the `Libraries` tab, select the JRE in the module path, click edit and change it to Java 17.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/aad58a26-c4c1-4440-b87f-8f976e1ae6cb)

title: NA
body:
Thanks!

It was indeed Java 17 -- in a different folder (Applications/EclipseApp/... rather than Library/Java/..., which is where 21 was installed). I reinstalled Eclipse, and that worked.

title: Out-of-date SWT ResourceManager ??
NA
body:
> com.swtdesigner.SWTResourceManager

That sounds really old. Only `org.eclipse.wb.swt.SWTResourceManager` is supported and that only because of backwards compatibility. In general, I'd suggest using the JFace resource manager.

title: NA
body: I'm closing this one. The `com.swtdesigner.SWTResourceManager ` has been replaced by the `org.eclipse.wb.swt.SWTResourceManager`. Though in general, I can only recommend using the JFace resource manager.

title: java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot read the array length because "prefixes" is null
body:
This is an exception that sporadically shows up in our application...
What seems to be happening is that the following properties of the Java project are not guaranteed to be set, by the time they are requested by WindowBuilder:

- JavaCore.CODEASSIST_LOCAL_PREFIXES
- JavaCore.CODEASSIST_LOCAL_SUFFIXES
- JavaCore.CODEASSIST_FIELD_PREFIXES
- JavaCore.CODEASSIST_FIELD_SUFFIXES

We use those properties to remove any prefixes and suffixes of the variables. Given that we're relying on JDT, I think it makes more sense to simply move on, rather than throwing an exception.

title: Mark support for old ResourceManager for removal
body:
As part of migrating to the JFace resource manager as part of #486, I think we should also make preparations to eventually get rid of the old implementation.

I propose that this removal is done via the following steps:
- Mark the corresponding methods in the WindowBuilder projects as `@Deprecated(forRemoval=true)`
- Adapt the builder to create a warning, whenever the old resource manager is referenced in user code
- Remove the old implementation in an unspecified, future release.

By creating a warning, we let the user know about the planned removal. And by waiting a few releases, we give them time to adjust their code, before we eventually drop the support.

body: There is still a hang on something about the contents of my lambda expressions. I wonder what I can do to debug this. However, the issue of the action performed line number is now resolved and is found correctly without any errors.

If it's stuck, then I would suggest to profile the IDE via [VisualVM](https://visualvm.github.io/). If you can take and upload a snapshot of e.g. the sampler, I can also take a look at it.

body:
What you described is standard modal behavior, its mostly the whole point. If I run your example, a window with just the close/minimize buttons comes up. If you close the window, then you get the string printed.

However, this isn't the behavior that seems to be the problem. There's clearly a difference in my example between a lambda calling the same set of code vs a standard action listener. If I toggle between one by commenting out the other, I get different behavior with the lambda causing eclipse to hang.

title: NA
body:
> What you described is standard modal behavior, its mostly the whole point. If I run your example, a window with just the close/minimize buttons comes up. If you close the window, then you get the string printed.

Right... apologies. I didn't notice the small frame popping up. 
But you have the same behavior with WindowBuilder. The modal dialog is opened, blocking WindowBuilder from switching to the design page. If you click on it, everything works again.

>  There's clearly a difference in my example between a lambda calling the same set of code vs a standard action listener.

When using the lambda expression, WindowBuilder tries to create a proper instance of the dialog, while it doesn't with anonymous classes. My point is that this is a general problem that will pop whenever modal dialogs are used, not just with listeners or lambda expressions.

title: NA
body: I've created #741 to keep track of the issue. As mentioned, the problem is the modal dialog. The lambda expression is merely the catalyst, but not the cause.

title: JMenuItems lose display resolution in a JMenu while editing
body: On OSX with Eclipse 4.31.0, and using the latest version of WindowBuilder, when working with JMenuItems inside of a JMenu, the text and menu seems like its losing focus/resolution as I edit it. For example, it starts like this: and if I alternate between the items, the whole menu contents start losing resolution/losing focus and the thing just seems like its trying to warp away. Probably the quickest way is just trying to add a JMenuItem and choosing a spot, just moving where the Item will go will quickly make the menu lose focus.

title: NA
body: I can't reproduce this issue on Linux, so I assume that's a Mac-specific problem. I can have a look if/when the the screenshots are taken but without an actual machine, there's probably not much else that I can do right now. 😦

title: NA
body: Just saw this SWT issue which seems to describe a similar problem: https://github.com/eclipse-platform/eclipse.platform.swt/issues/1649

title: NA
body: Good eye! Yes this seems quite similar, and funny enough, I tried it a couple weeks ago to see if its resolved yet and it still behaves the same. When/if a solution comes up, I'll be glad to try it again.

title: Modal dialog blocking design page from being opened
NA
body:
@igarshep 

I've added your use case to our test suite and I've tested the changed with the code snippet you provided. Changes are high that WindowBuilder will no longer block when using the modal dialog. 🎉 
Can you check the upcoming nightly build again, to check whether this is the case?

In any case, thank you for reporting the problem, especially for debugging and providing the minimal reproducer!

title: NA
body:
I'll verify, especially as I'm looking forward to this being fixed. Currently I'm having to comment out some buttons just to get into a design tab.

And thank you for how quick you are able to address the issue. Reporting/debugging couldn't have been as hard as the work you put in, so I seriously appreciate it!

title: NA

title: JDialog super constructor causes exception
body:
Hello, we meet again so soon..

Here is a sample of code that causes the problem:

    public class TestView extends JDialog {

        public TestView() {
           super(new JFrame());
           final JPanel panel = new JPanel();
           getContentPane().add(panel, BorderLayout.CENTER);
        }
    }

If I comment out 

      super(new JFrame()); 

it'll work again.

title: NA
body:
Hm... looks like the dummy object is causing problems. Perhaps my initial approach was too complicated and I have to accept that JDialogs can't be parsed properly. I.e. they should categorically be replaced by a dummy object. Otherwise you have endless combinations to somehow make them modal.

That said, you won't be happy with the preview, even if this code snippet wouldn't cause an error...

Because the empty JFrame is the owner of the dialog, is is treated as the entry point for the editor. Which has the beautiful side-effect that nothing you add to the dialog will be captured.

Meaning you get something like this:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/423db3be-b919-4d40-b5fa-beae480a662e)

As opposed to this:
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/9e46222f-ad27-46aa-ad37-e28a4dc84f0e)

But I think I have a solution for both problems.

title: NA
body: Let's hope the second approach works... Instead of creating a stub, windows created inside the root widget are simply ignored.

title: Please avoid showBanner() to be called from org.burningwave.core.assembler.StaticComponentContainer
body:
Please set the property called `HIDE_BANNER` somewhere early in `DesignerPlugin.java` to get rid of the awful banner printed by the code:

```
	DesignerPlugin.exportAllModulesToAllModules() line: 74	
	DesignerPlugin.start(BundleContext) line: 68	
```

This happens when launching an Eclipse IDE-based product from Eclipse IDE itself when Windows Builder plugin is installed in Eclipse. It is also likely that this output is not seen in the Eclipse IDE itself, because `System.out` calls are not redirected to a console or a log file.

It would be very nice to get rid of the very ugly output in the `System.out` console originating from the Windows Builder plugin using `org.burningwave:core` artifact that prints a banner using `org.burningwave.core.assembler.StaticComponentContainer.showBanner()`.

Lines 362-364 in that code, called from its static constructor:

```java
if (!Objects.toBoolean(IterableObjectHelper.resolveValue(onGlobalPropertiesforNamedKey(Configuration.Key.BANNER_HIDE)))) {
				showBanner();
			}
```

produces this output, caught in our System.out redirector pipe:

```
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]   ___                                                                        
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  (  _`\                      _

[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  |  _ <'( ) ( )( '__)/' _ `\| |/' _ `\ /'_ `\( ) ( ) ( ) /'_` )( ) ( ) /'__`\
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  | (_) )| (_) || |   | ( ) || || ( ) |( (_) || \_/ \_/ |( (_| || \_/ |(  ___/
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  (____/'`\___/'(_)   (_) (_)(_)(_) (_)`\__  |`\___x___/'`\__,_)`\___/'`\____)
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.942  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]                                       ( )_) |                                
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.943  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]                                        \___/'                                
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.943  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.943  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]      
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:18.943  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  
[INFO]    10 Apr 2024  23:43:19.023  <system>  <stdout>  [stdout,5,main]  jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$PlatformClassLoader@65209f9b instantiated
```

This output is very surprising and I tought there were some "virus" or "malwear" causing it, I didn't use Window Builder previously.
(The line `jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$PlatformClassLoader@65209f9b instantiated` comes perhaps from elsewhere).

We implemented for now a workaround to remove this banner using the code below, but it slows down `System.out` calls unnecessarily.

```java
  /**
   * Should ignore this call? I.e. to remove Banner from
   * "org.burningwave.core.assembler.StaticComponentContainer.showBanner()"
   */
  private boolean shouldIgnore()
    {
    return (is_stdout
         && StackWalker.getInstance(StackWalker.Option.RETAIN_CLASS_REFERENCE)
             .walk(sf1->sf1
                 .limit(14) // Only 14 frames down...
                 .filter(sf2->sf2.getMethodName().equals("showBanner") && sf2.getClassName().equals("org.burningwave.core.assembler.StaticComponentContainer"))
                 .findFirst()
                 .orElse(null))!=null);
    }
```

title: NA
body: The banner.hide property is set to "true" with #746 , to avoid the banner popping up.

title: Panels in Windowbuilder Design tab are empty
body:
One GUI class in my application displays empty panels in the Design tab.  The Design tab opens and does not display any errors.  It looks like this:
![WindowBuilderDesignTab](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/5721445/09523872-4dfa-4468-a429-4c57da08364e)
The code is in the attached file.  I left out the import statements, but if needed I can add them.
[GearRatioView.txt](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/14949972/GearRatioView.txt)

This class obtains data from other classes that communicate with a database and uses a renderer to format the output in a JTable. Additional other classes are used as entity classes to hold the data during processing.   I did not include these but can upload them if needed.  The output (the application runs as it should) displays the data in a formatted table as shown below.  While some of the formatting may look peculiar, I can assure you that it is running properly.
![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/5721445/35d38695-f084-4df2-a2e8-6ca7a761173a)
I have another class in the same project that does not exhibit this behavior but displays in the Design tab correctly.  The difference in the two classes is mostly the table in this one--the other one does not have a table.
I am using eclipse 2024-03, Windowbuilder 1.15.0 and I've tried this with JavaSE-1.8 and JavaSE-17.

title: NA
body:
Even without the additional classes, I am able to open the widget without problems. So I don't believe there is anything wrong with the example you've provided.

![image](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/assets/70652978/1b3426d5-96d6-40f1-b4b8-97c3738861f6)

Given that not even the palette is rendered, I assume that an exception is thrown internally. If you go the error view by clicking "Window" -> "Show View" -> "Error Log" in the main menu, is there anything logged?

title: NA
body:
Thanks! That already tracks down the problem by quite a lot!

> One thing I should mention is that when I comment out the table model, WindowBuilder works just as you saw it, but of course, with no data.

Hm... that matches the stack trace you've provided. For some reason, the array returned by `calculatedGearRatios.calcGearRatios(internalRatios, frontSprockets, rearSprockets)` is `null`, as opposed to containing the table entries.

Would it be possible to provided the remaining Java classes? At this point I'm certain that something goes wrong when processing the Java code. So being able to see what's actually happening would help quite a lot.

title: NA
body:
[BicycleGears.zip](https://github.com/eclipse-windowbuilder/windowbuilder/files/14962275/BicycleGears.zip)
I’ve attached a zip file with the entire project.  There are 4 packages: controller, model, test and ui.  You can ignore the classes in the test package.  There are two files, DbConfig.java and DbQueries.java, that contain the database connection information and the queries, but I don’t think you’ll need any of the database data.  At this stage of development, the data is hardcoded into the entity classes.  There is one exception and that involves duplicate gear ratios.  Rather than include the data here, I think it would be easier for you to comment out line 270 [ “formatTable();” ] in the GearRatioView.java class, since the behavior of WindowBuilder is the same whether you format the data or not.

Two other files, HashMapDuplicates and TableCellBackgroundRenderer in the controller package are also not used.

The way the program works is that it uses the three distinct sets of data, internal gear ratios, front wheel tooth count and rear wheel tooth count to calculate the ratios..  There are 3 internal gears, 3 front wheel sprockets and 9 rear wheel sprockets.  This yields 81 total gear ratios.  These are displayed in the table.  Many of the ratios repeat themselves so these repetitions are colored the same, but each repetition has its own color.  The first and last columns in the table display the rear tooth count.  The headers are “”Rear teeth” for those columns and the others are the front teeth counts.  These repeat three times—once for each internal gear.

title: NA
body:
Awesome! I can reproduce the error on my side and was able to isolate the problem to the following line:

> ratios[i][j] = frontToothCount[j] / rearToothCount[k] * internalRatios[i];

The `rearToothCount` array is -for some reason- not initialized properly. So you end up with `frontToothCount[j] / 0 * internalRatios[i];`, leading to a division by zero. I have to further investigate why this is the case, though.
`

title: NA
body:
Correction: It's a division by `null`, not `0`.

> java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "java.lang.Double.doubleValue()" because "internalRatios[i]" is null
